Dialogue:
[doctor] . next patient is michelle king . date of birth : 05/07/1982 . please use toc template . she was admitted to district regional hospital on 06/29/2021 , and was discharged on 07/02/2021 . the patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to , uh , prior spinal cord injury . she was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness , significant constipation , and reported diaphoresis . she was evaluated in the emergency department where she was , uh , febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000 . there were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection , but she was treated with iv antibiotic therapy . she had labile blood pressure , headache , and vomiting . in the end , she slowly improved . she does have a supra-pubic catheter . cultures were obtained and reviewed . she was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms . she presents today to follow up regarding these concerns . hi , michelle . how are you doing ?
[patient] not too bad . and yourself ?
[doctor] i'm good , thanks . so , it looks like you had an infection , right ?
[patient] yeah . but you know , i really do n't think it was a uti .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i told them when i went to the er ... is that your phone ?
[doctor] it is , yeah . it listens to you and me and it does all of my documentation . it's pretty good stuff . um , tell me what's going on .
[patient] it is , in my humble opinion , that i was just constipated and that was what was causing my blood pressure to be so high . and i hardly pooped when i was there . then when i got home i had a massive poop and i felt much better . i told them that when i was admitted , and they did x-rays and everything , but they said , " no , " as they did n't think that was n't ... that was it . but you know , i felt so much better when i got home and finally pooped .
[doctor] okay . um , and the white cell count was the only thing that i think they were kind of concerned about because it was a little high .
[patient] so i wondered if automatic dysreflexia can affect the white count ?
[doctor] typically , it does n't .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] but , i mean , when i looked at the urine cultures that they checked , the cultures are not very impressive .
[patient] yeah , that's what they said .
[doctor] and when i go back and look , sometimes your white count is just elevated a little bit , and last year it was normal , so ...
[patient] hm .
[doctor] but in saying that , you know , inflammation can do that . so , yeah , you could be backed up and inflamed .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] uh , they did n't do a cat scan , they just did an x-ray . but you feel like you're back to your normal self now ?
[patient] yeah . i mean , i went in because i knew my blood pressure was out of control .
[doctor] mm-hmm .
[patient] it was giving me a headache and making me throw up . and i know , at that point , i'm at the loss of what i can do at home .
[doctor] yeah , it was good that you went in .
[patient] so i went in and they made me feel better , and then i went home , as you know .
[doctor] well , maybe that's all it was .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] so you're doing good otherwise ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] good . let me take a quick listen to you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . go ahead and take a few deep breaths . and breathe normally . now take several deep breaths . and two more . okay , good . you can relax . any pain or discomfort anywhere ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] great . so here are my thoughts .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] you may recall it was extremely hot during that period leading up to you going to the hospital . i do n't know if you were inside for the most part ?
[patient] yeah , it was pretty hot , was n't it ? and i go out a bit , but i do tend to stay in more when it's hot .
[doctor] okay . well , if you do get dehydrated even just a little bit it can lead to further , um , or worsening constipation issues .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i've had a lot of patients over the last couple of weeks coming in with just weird stuff , and i blame that a little bit on how hot and humid it was the last two weeks of june . so what i would do is wait a couple of weeks and then , if you could , come back in and we could do some , uh , complete blood work , uh , including your white blood cells and a full panel of cholesterol , since it's been a while .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and it should normalize , but it's too soon to do it now . um , but maybe if i put some labs in you could come in in two to three weeks ?
[patient] sure , i can do that .
[doctor] great . so that appointment will let us kill a bird ... two birds with one stone since you're due to get blood work anyways for cholesterol .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and then , i just wanted to make sure that the white count is okay , because if it remains elevated then that means there's something else going on with your bowels .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i do n't think that's what we'll find , but we'll see .
[patient] i mean , i knew going in that i had n't had a regular bowel movement in a while , even though i drink the miralax every day .
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] when i do n't go , i double up on that .
[doctor] have i ever given you lactulose ? it would be a medicine you use in , um , conjunction with miralax . sort of a rescue type thing .
[patient] is that the stuff that comes in a bottle ?
[doctor] yes .
[patient] then , yes . i have it . it takes about two days to work and then it's a brutal two days .
[doctor] got it . yeah , it can be a little rough , but it works .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] all right . so we have our plan . any questions ?
[patient] yeah , well , i would like to talk to you about covid , if we can .
[doctor] sure . so where are you at when it comes to the vaccine ?
[patient] i am unvaccinated .
[doctor] so what are your concerns about the vaccine ?
[patient] well , we do n't know the side effects .
[doctor] correct , we do n't .
[patient] it's too soon to tell the side effects , and i'm hearing more and more reports of people getting what's now termed as " vaccine injury " .
[doctor] right .
[patient] which i had never heard of before . i do n't know if it is a new term or not , but my take on the whole thing is that i'm young and healthy enough to beat it , even if my respiratory is limited . i also take a lot of vitamin c.
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i also take multivitamins and i'm closely monitored . so i guess i do n't feel as though i really the vaccine .
[doctor] well , my thoughts are that you actually should be vaccinated . i think you are high risk . if you get covid it's not going to be good for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and i think it's safe . i mean , i understand and hear you . all of these stories out there about this , uh , regarding the vaccine . but i've seen all the bad things that could happen from covid . people have died in my practice , and i do n't disagree that if you got covid you'd probably be okay .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] but i would consider you as someone that would make me a little bit concerned . i have had healthy people die from covid .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i've had some people get really , really sick from it . so personally , i believe that this vaccine is completely safe . i really think that .
[patient] all of them ?
[doctor] yeah , i do , i do . i think there are side effects from all vaccines , so you have to go back and think about it . do you get flu shot every year ?
[patient] no , i do n't .
[doctor] right , well , it's hard for me to convince you because you're making a consistent viewpoint .
[patient] well , i am open-minded to this .
[doctor] mm-hmm . to me , it's , you know , a lot of the stuff out there is fear and most of us health providers have gotten the vaccine . we've seen what the virus can do . i also have gotten all of my kids vaccinated .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so i'm not concerned about the side effects of this . i do n't think it does anything . um , and we have vaccinated 50 % of the country .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] the er is full of these vaccines .
[patient] i understand .
[doctor] so there are definitely potential side effects to the vaccine . i mean , there's guillain-barre , and all these things that could happen from the vaccine , but they're just very rare . my thing for you is i'm not convinced that there's alternative stuff or even the treatment we have , like the monoclonal antibodies , that will give help , but it's just my opinion .
[patient] well , that's what i'm here for .
[doctor] yeah . right now the numbers are low . even with the delta variant , when it starts mutating , it's actually good because it becomes more contagious , but less deadly .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so that's what's gon na happen with covid . that's what's mo- most of the science supports and this is how most pandemics end , is that the virus starts losing its potency .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] but think about it , and if you have any more questions you can certainly let me know , okay ?
[patient] will do .
[doctor] all right . anything else we can discuss today ?
[patient] nope . i think i'm all set . thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome . so we'll see you in two to three weeks . have a good rest of your day .
[patient] thanks , you too .
[doctor] next line heading will be " acute to chronic constipation " . she believes her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia , from her quadriplegia that typically occurs . she did have a lot of vital signs changes , including blood pressure fluctuations . the patient feels like she has a good bowel regimen , including taking the miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation . she feels like this was less likely a true urinary tract infection and was just related to her constipation . however , we did have a good discussion regarding her leukocytosis .
[doctor] i would recommend just in the next three or four weeks to come back in for some updated fasting labs , and we'll repeat the cbc just to make sure her white blood cells tend downward . uh , next line and heading will be " quadriplegia " . um , next line and heading will be " covid vaccine status " . again , she's hesitant . we had a good discussion , and i recommended that the only true preventative mechanism for covid is the vaccine . i do not believe that supplements are necessarily going to help stave this off . i would be concerned if she does n't get the vaccine and i would consider her at high risk based on her quadriplegia status . she does not want to get covid . however , she needs to make these decisions . she is somewhat homeopathic .

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up visit regarding recent admission for urinary tract infection (UTI) and constipation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 39-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for follow-up regarding her UTI and constipation. She notes that she experienced increasing concerns for spasms, lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have a fever and elevated white blood cell count of 23,000. She received IV antibiotics and was subsequently discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms. The patient denies any other medical problems.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up regarding recent hospitalization for infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 39-year-old female who presents for follow-up regarding her recent hospitalization for infection. She reports that she experienced increased concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have a fever and elevated white blood cell count of 23,000. There were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection, but she was treated with IV antibiotics. She also reports having labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting. In the end, she slowly improved. She does have a suprapubic catheter. Cultures were obtained and reviewed. She was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Constipation 
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury and reports decreased bowel movements despite using Miralax daily. She also uses Lactulose for severe constipation. Her hospitalization was thought to be due to dysreflexia from her quadriplegia rather than UTI. 
Plan: 
- Will continue current bowel regimen. 
- Will increase Miralax dosage to twice daily. 
- Will start Lactulose for severe constipation. 

2. Leukocytosis
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury and reports increased white blood cell count. Differential diagnosis includes stress response vs. infectious process. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain CBC with differential. 
- If WBC continues to rise, will perform further evaluation such as abdominal CT scan. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2-3 weeks for repeat CBC with differential and discussion of results.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:  
1. Acute to Chronic Constipation  
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to a previous spinal cord injury. She experienced increased concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have a fever and elevated white blood cell count. She had labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting.
Plan:  
- Will obtain CBC and chemistry profile to assess for electrolyte imbalance and leukocytosis.  
- Will continue current bowel regimen and add lactulose for severe constipation.  
- Will refer to physical therapy for exercise and mobility training.  
2. Leukocytosis  
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to a previous spinal cord injury. She experienced increased concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have a fever and elevated white blood cell count. She had labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting.
Plan:  
- Will obtain CBC and chemistry profile to assess for electrolyte imbalance and leukocytosis.  
- If WBC continues to be elevated, will consider other causes such as UTI or inflammation.  
Follow-up instructions:  
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for reassessment of WBC count and management of constipation.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Acute to Chronic Constipation
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury. She experienced increased concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have fever and elevated WBC count. She was treated with IV antibiotics. She had labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting. In the end, she slowly improved. She does have a suprapubic catheter. Cultures were obtained and reviewed. She was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms.
Plan:
- Will continue current bowel regimen, including Miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation.
- Will obtain CBC and chemistry panel to assess for electrolyte imbalance and other causes of constipation.
- Will refer to colorectal surgery for evaluation of possible surgical intervention for constipation.

2. Leukocytosis
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury. She experienced increased concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have fever and elevated WBC count. She was treated with IV antibiotics. She had labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting. In the end, she slowly improved. She does have a suprapubic catheter. Cultures were obtained and reviewed. She was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms.
Plan:
- Will obtain CBC and chemistry panel to assess for electrolyte imbalance and other causes of leukocytosis.
- Will refer to infectious disease specialist for further evaluation and management of leukocytosis.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2-3 weeks for follow-up of leukocytosis and constipation.

[patient] nope . nowhere .

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Resistant Hypertension
Assessment: The patient has resistant hypertension, despite being on multiple medications at maximum doses. He is at increased risk of cardiovascular disease due to his hypertension. His blood pressure is currently 146-155/80-85 mmHg.
Plan:
- Add spironolactone 25mg Qday to his current regimen.
- Monitor potassium and sodium levels in two weeks.
- If not controlled on spironolactone, refer to the resistant hypertension clinic.

Follow-up instructions:
- Follow up in 2 weeks for labwork and blood pressure check.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient has persistent hypertension despite maximally tolerated doses of antihypertensive medications. He has a positive family history of hypertension, and may have underlying resistance hypertension.
Plan:
- Add spironolactone 25mg Qday to current medication regimen.
- Monitor potassium and sodium levels in two weeks.
- If not controlled on spironolactone, consider referral to resistant hypertension clinic.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for monitoring of potassium and sodium levels.
- Follow up with primary care provider as needed.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right foot pain due to Lisfranc fracture
Assessment: Patient presents with right foot pain, bruising, swelling, and positive piano key test of the first and second metatarsals. X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and the presence of a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space.
Plan:
- Will order MRI to further assess the fracture and any injury to the ligaments.
- Recommend surgery to place the bones in their proper positions using plates and screws to prevent further complications.
- Will refer to physical therapy after surgery.


Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week for postoperative check.
- Follow up with primary care provider regarding hypertension management.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) 
Assessment: The patient has a history of CAD, s/p RCA stent placement in ___ and recent interior STEMI with PCI of LAD on ___. He reports no chest pain or shortness of breath today. His EKG shows a normal sinus rhythm and good R wave progression. Echo showed a reduced EF of 35%. 
Plan: 
- Continue Aspirin 81mg Qday, Brilanta 90mg BID, Lipitor 80mg Qday, Toprol XL 50mg Qday. 
- Refer to Cardiac Rehab. 
2. Reduced Left Ventricular Function (EF 35%) and Moderate Mitral Regurgitation 
Assessment: The patient has a new diagnosis of reduced LV function and MR. He is currently asymptomatic. 
Plan: 
- Continue Lisinopril 20mg Qday. 
- Will repeat echo in 2 months. 
3. Acute Heart Failure 
Assessment: The patient has evidence of volume overload with lower extremity edema. 
Plan: 
- Start Lasix 40mg Qday. 
- Add Aldactone 12.5mg Qday. 
- Monitor weight and electrolytes closely. 
4. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's BP is well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Continue current antihypertensive regimen. 
- Consider nutrition counseling to discuss alternative diet options. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 6 weeks for follow-up.

- Refer to Cardiac Rehab.

Plan:

- Add Aldactone 12.5mg Qday. 
- Repeat echo in 2 months. 
3. Moderate Mitral Regurgitation 
Assessment: Patient has moderate MR due to CAD. He is compliant with his medications. 
Plan: 
- Monitor closely. 
4. Acute Diastolic Heart Failure 
Assessment: Patient has acute diastolic HF due to CAD. He is retaining fluid. 
Plan: 
- Start Lasix 40mg Qday. 
- Add Aldactone 12.5mg Qday. 
- Encourage low sodium diet. 
5. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure is well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Monitor closely. 
6. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 
Assessment: Patient has type 2 DM. He is compliant with his metformin and monitoring his sugar levels. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin. 
7. Hyperlipidemia 
Assessment: Patient has hyperlipidemia. 
Plan: 
- Continue Statin. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Hypertension 
Assessment: Uncontrolled hypertension, currently taking chlorthalidone 25mg Qday but takes it only every other day. 
Plan: 
- Continue chlorthalidone 25mg Qday. 
- Encourage patient to take her medication everyday by setting up reminders on her phone. 
- Monitor blood pressure 3x/week at home. 
- Refer to nutritionist for education on reducing sodium intake. 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: Poorly controlled diabetes, HbA1C 8.6%. Currently taking metformin 1000mg BID. 
Plan: 
- Increase metformin to 1500mg BID. 
- Continue checking blood glucose levels regularly. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for reassessment.
Note_2:

1. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient has uncontrolled hypertension, likely due to poor compliance with medications and diet. 
Plan: 
- Continue current medication regimen (chlorthalidone) and advise patient to take it every day. 
- Monitor blood pressure three times a week using a blood pressure monitor at home. 
- Schedule a follow-up appointment in one month to reassess blood pressure control. 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: Patient has type II diabetes, currently controlled with metformin. 
Plan: 
- Increase metformin dosage to 1500mg per day. 
- Advise patient to continue checking blood glucose levels regularly. 
3. Dietary counseling 
Assessment: Patient has a poor diet, high in sodium. 
Plan: 
- Refer patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling.

- Continue to monitor blood glucose levels. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up.

The patient denies any swelling or pain at the time of the injury. However, he notes that the swelling has subsided somewhat, but the knee remains tender to palpation. The patient is currently bearing weight on the affected leg, but he reports that it feels loose and unstable. He is unable to perform terminal extension or flexion due to pain. Palpation of the knee elicits pain, particularly on the medial joint line. The patient is unable to extend the knee fully, and is limited by pain at terminal flexion. The patient's toes are warm and neurovascularly intact. Muscle strength in both lower extremities is 5 out of 5.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee injury, likely ACL tear 
Assessment: Patient presented with right knee pain, swelling, and limited mobility after a recent right knee injury during a soccer game. Physical exam revealed marked limp, significant effusion, and positive lachman exam. MRI will be ordered to evaluate the integrity of the ACL. 
Plan: 
- Order MRI of the right knee. 
- Start meloxicam 50mg daily for pain and inflammation. 
- Instruct patient to use ice packs and elevate the affected knee. 
- Limit activities, including jogging, until further evaluation. 
2. Dog health 
Assessment: Patient reported that his dog is doing well and enjoying playing outside but will not be able to do that for a little bit. 
Plan: 
- Provide support and resources for pet care.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee injury, likely ACL tear 
Assessment: The patient presented with a right knee injury after a pickup soccer game, which is consistent with an ACL tear. He has pain, swelling, and limited mobility in his right knee. Physical exam revealed marked limb on the right leg upon ambulation, a small amount of edema in the right knee, and pain on palpation of the medial joint line. Neurovascular exam showed no deficits. Muscle strength testing showed a grade 5 (normal) in both lower extremities. MRI will be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. 
Plan: 
- Order MRI of the right knee. 
- Start anti-inflammatory medication meloxicam 50mg daily. 
- Ice the knee if needed. 
- Wear a knee immobilizer and use crutches when walking. 
- Limit work activities and avoid jogging until further evaluation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:

Plan:

- Will start meloxicam 50mg daily for pain relief and inflammation reduction. 
- Will recommend the patient to wear a knee immobilizer and use crutches when walking. 
- Will advise the patient to limit his work activities and avoid jogging until further evaluation. 
2. Dog health 
Assessment: The patient reports that his dog is doing well. 
Plan: 
- No specific intervention needed at this time.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right elbow pain due to medial epicondylitis 
Assessment: The patient has right elbow pain, tenderness to palpation at the medial epicondyle, and pain with resisted pronation of the right forearm. Physical examination shows pain with flexion and bending of the wrist. 
Plan: 
- Rest and immobilization of the right arm using a sling. 
- Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day. 
- Take 600 mg of ibuprofen (3 pills) every 6 hours with food for one week. 
- Hold off on pottery for the next couple of weeks to allow the arm to heal. 
- Recommend follow-up in 2 weeks to assess progress.

Physical exam reveals mild tenderness to palpation at the medial epicondyle and pain with resisted pronation of the right forearm. Differential diagnosis includes tennis elbow, golfer's elbow, or fracture. 
Plan:

- Sling for the right arm. 
- Ibuprofen 600mg TID for one week. 
- Hold off on pottery for the next couple of weeks. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient has a history of hypertension, currently well controlled with lisinopril 10mg Qday. 
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 10mg Qday. 
3. Diabetes 
Assessment: Patient has a history of diabetes, currently managed with metformin 500mg BID. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg BID. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:

1. Right elbow pain 
Assessment: Medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and damage to the tendons in her arm. 
Plan: 
- Rest the arm in a sling while awake. 
- Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes x3 times a day. 
- Take 600mg ibuprofen (3 pills) every 6 hours with food for 1 week. 
- Hold off on pottery for the next few weeks to allow the arm to heal. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.

Plan:
- Continue lisinopril 10mg Qday and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday.
- Encourage compliance with medications.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week for blood pressure check and discussion of any concerns or side effects.
- Return to clinic in 1 month for repeat blood pressure check

- Reviewed side effects and risks.
- Potential benefits of alcohol cessation include improved hypertension control, reduced risk of liver disease, and reduced risk of cancer.
2. Hypertension

Plan:

- Recommend upgrading influenza vaccination and Shingrix.

label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE 
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Left knee pain. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left knee pain. The patient reports that she injured her knee while running with her niece, who is learning how to ride a bike without training wheels. She fell and twisted her knee in a funny way. She has been limping since the injury and the pain has not improved. She rates her pain as a 4 out of 10. She has been taking Tylenol and wrapping her knee with kinesiology tape. She cannot take ibuprofen due to a previous ulcer. The patient denies hearing a popping sound at the time of injury. On examination, the patellar tendon is tender to palpation. There is moderate range of motion, positive effusion, and positive laxity. A x-ray of the left knee was obtained and showed no fractures or bony abnormalities.

The patient twisted her knee and fell, and she believes she may have strained her medial collateral ligament (MCL) in the process. She reports that her pain began approximately one week prior to presentation and has been steadily worsening. She rates her pain as a 4 out of 10, and she describes it as a throbbing pain. She denies hearing a pop or feeling instability in her knee. She has been taking Tylenol and wrapping her knee with kinesiology tape for relief. She is unable to take ibuprofen due to a history of stomach ulcers.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain 
Assessment: The patient presents with left knee pain after falling while running with her niece, who is learning how to ride a bike without training wheels. Physical exam shows tenderness to palpation over the medial aspect of the left knee, with moderate range of motion and positive patellar grind test. X-ray of the left knee is normal. 
Plan: 
- Will start tramadol 50mg Q8H PRN pain. 
- Will provide knee immobilizer and recommend icing three to four times a day for 20-30 minutes at a time. 
- Recommend avoiding activities that involve running or jumping for 3 weeks. 
- If symptoms worsen or fail to improve within a month, will consider MRI to evaluate for possible meniscal tears or other injuries.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. MCL strain 
Assessment: The patient presents with left knee pain after falling while playing with her niece. She has pain on both sides, more on the medial side. She reports hearing a pop when she twisted her knee. Exam shows edema, effusion, moderate range of motion, pain on flexion and extension, and negative lachman's test, valgus test, and varus test. X-ray of the left knee is normal. 
Plan: 
- Will start Tramadol 50mg Q8H PRN pain. 
- Will provide knee immobilizer and recommend ice application 3x/day for 20-30minutes each session. 
- Recommend avoiding running for 3 weeks. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- If symptoms worsen or fail to improve within a month, return to clinic for further evaluation.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Left knee MCL strain 
Assessment: Patient presents with left knee pain after falling while running with her niece. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation on the medial aspect of the knee, effusion, and limited range of motion. X-ray shows no fracture or bony abnormality. Differential diagnosis includes meniscal tear or osteochondritis dissecans, although these are less likely given lack of locking or catching sensation. 
Plan: 
- Will start Tramadol 50mg Q8H PRN for pain control. 
- Will provide knee immobilizer and recommend icing 3x/day for 20min each. 
- Recommend avoiding running for 3 weeks. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

Dialogue:
[doctor] brittany edwards , 07 , 1898 . she is a return visit for ibs with functional abdominal pain , nausea , vomiting . ms. edwards is a pleasant , 32-year-old female who was last seen in august of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain , who was diagnosed with irritable bowl that was treated with bentyl .
[doctor] she had a previous prescription for reglan that she received from the emergency room that she used as needed for nausea . she was instructed to start a low dose fiber supplement , such as citrucel , daily , probiotics to help with gas and bloating , bentyl up to four times daily for intestinal cramping , and stop reglan and use zofran as needed . neuromodulators such as elavil and buspar were discussed but not started .
[doctor] hello , how are you ?
[patient] i'm okay .
[doctor] good . how have you been feeling ?
[patient] not so good .
[doctor] yeah , so my nurse told me you have been going out to eat some on friday nights and saturday nights and that you have had some spicy foods or spicy shrimp .
[patient] yeah , i have .
[doctor] okay . well , your gut probably does not always appreciate that .
[patient] no , it does n't like it at all .
[doctor] yeah , so ibs is one of those things where you are very sensitive to certain things such as spicy foods or fatty foods and alcohol . and this can cause lower belly stuff like cramps , or you can get upper belly stuff such as nausea .
[patient] i've been getting both .
[doctor] okay . um , so how frequently have you been getting or having a bowel movement on normal days ?
[patient] i'm starting to notice it's between two and three times a day .
[doctor] okay . and are they soft stools or formed stools ?
[patient] um , they're formed .
[doctor] okay . and after you have gone out either drinking with your friends , do you tend to have more diarrhea ?
[patient] yeah , i do .
[doctor] okay . do you feel it's the food or the alcohol or both ?
[patient] uh , well usually we go to friday's restaurant . i always eat pasta , the chicken alfredo .
[doctor] okay . i can s- i can bet it's the alfredo sauce .
[patient] but it normally does n't bother me .
[doctor] okay . well , pasta can make you bloated , uh , but it does n't usually cause diarrhea . grilled chi- uh , grilled chicken is usually all right . alfredo , though , is higher in fat , and it does contain dairy . but you're saying it usually does n't bother you ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . what type of alcohol drink do you drink when you are there ? is it a sweet drink ?
[patient] most of the time it's either tequila or dark liquor . i prefer patron , but if i get brown liquor , i only get two . um , every now and again , i'll drink a martini .
[doctor] sometimes it's the mixer they tend to put in the drinks , but it can be a variety of things . um , so when you're not eating out or drinking , what we do on a daily basis does help keep us regular , so when it does flare up , it c- it might not be as bad . um , have you had any luck using the fiber like citrucel regularly ?
[patient] um , no . i guess i need to find a new drink .
[doctor] okay . and how is it during the week ?
[patient] like what i eat ?
[doctor] yeah , and with the diarrhea and abdomal- um , abdominal pain .
[patient] right now , i'm still having the cramping and sharp pains , so i've been avoiding heavy foods . i did have some fried chicken today , though .
[doctor] and was everything all right after that ?
[patient] yeah , for the most part .
[doctor] okay . remember , it's also the portion sizes . so i mean , if you eat a little and you feel fine , then that's okay . you have to just really watch the portions .
[patient] okay , good . i ca n't go out- go without some fried chicken at least once in a while .
[doctor] sounds good . all right , well let's take a look at you today , and we'll do a brief physical exam . you will hear me call out some findings . i will answer any questions , and we will discuss once we have finished the exam .
[patient] sounds good .
[doctor] all right . so the patient is alert and cooperative , appears stated age . all right . i'm going to listen to your heart and lungs . and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally . heart regular rate and rhythm . all right , so if you could just lay back for me , and i'll examine your abdomen .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . do you have any tenderness ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] okay . so the abdomen is soft , non-tender . no masses or organomegaly . and let me take a listen . normal active bowel sounds . all right . you can go ahead and sit up now . thank you .
[doctor] all right , so first i want you to try citrucel . it does come in a tablet . you should use it twice daily for regularity . then i would say , if you know you're going out and will possibly have diarrhea as a result , you can go ahead and use your bentyl 20 milligrams . you can do one tablet before you eat , and then repeat up to four times daily . and then on days when you feel good , you do n't have to use anything . um , and then on friday before you leave the house , you can take a bentyl and put one in your pocket for later , and then you can repeat the same thing on saturday if you want , and that will be totally fine .
[patient] okay , that sounds good .
[doctor] okay . and so your bentyl , that's the anti-spasm medication , and i would take the higher dose .
[patient] can i get a refill of that ?
[doctor] yes , absolutely . uh , so take one tablet about 30 to 45 minutes before leaving the house and then the second tablet at the restaurant . then with the nausea , um , i think we should try and see if you can recognize a pattern with what you are eating and drinking , um , um , about , like , what makes it worse .
[patient] yeah , i noticed i've been doing better with drinking water instead of sodas .
[doctor] okay , good . and then for your zofran , i would n't take that ahead of time . just plan on drinking plenty of water .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay , and you can take it , but before you do , we want to try to reduce the triggers . uh , so watch out for greasy or fatty foods and sugary drinks .
[patient] okay , i can do that .
[doctor] okay . and so , however , if it is not just these isolated inci- incidents and the symptoms are happening all the time , we could put you on a long term medication that would take ... that you would take every night . and so then you do n't have to use so much bentyl or the zofran . how do you feel about that ?
[patient] i was actually going to ask you about something like that to help avoid flares altogether .
[doctor] yeah , there is . and it actually works on the chemicals in your brain that are causing your gut to be overly sensitive . one is called elavil , but the only drawback is that it can make you a little sleepy . how does that sound ?
[patient] that sounds like a much better plan .
[doctor] okay , great . we can definitely do that . uh , just take it every night before bedtime .
[patient] okay , that sounds good . thank you so much .
[doctor] you're welcome . and so i have gone ahead and sent your prescriptions to your pharmacy . just give us a call if you have any questions or need us for anything else . and then let's plan on touching base through mychart email in about a month to just check in to see how you're doing with symptoms . okay ?
[patient] okay , that sounds good . thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome , and have a good rest of your day .
[doctor] so review of symptoms is positive for diarrhea , nausea , and abdominal pain . assessment and plan . brittany edwards is a pleasant female with ibs and functional abdominal pain , aggravated by high stress , poor eating habits , and poor sleeping habits . i've encouraged dietary and lifestyle modifications , as well as starting a neuromodulator such as elavil 25 milligrams at bedtime for ibs .
[doctor] she can use bentyl 20 milligrams as needed 30 to 45 minutes prior to eating out at a restaurant . she can also use zofran if needed . however , i have encouraged her to reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption . i have asked her to follow up in one month by emailing over mychart regarding any side effects and issues , or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed .
label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Irritable bowel syndrome with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 32-year-old female who was last seen in August of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain. She has been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and has been treated with Bentyl and Reglan. The patient reports that her symptoms have improved since treatment; however, she continues to experience occasional flares of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. These symptoms occur primarily after eating out, particularly when consuming spicy foods or fatty foods. The patient states that she often experiences diarrhea following these episodes. She prefers to avoid heavy foods and drinks, but occasionally indulges in fried chicken. The patient notes that she has tried using Citrucel, which helped somewhat. However, she has not found relief with Zofran.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 32-year-old female who was last seen in August of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and treated with Bentyl. The patient reports experiencing frequent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain associated with eating out at restaurants and consuming alcohol. She has tried Citrucel and Reglan in the past, but they have not provided adequate relief. She denies any recent changes in bowel movements, including frequency, consistency, or blood in the stool. She states that her diarrhea is typically associated with alcohol consumption. She prefers to avoid heavy foods and has been able to tolerate small amounts of fried chicken.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 32-year-old female who was last seen in August of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and was treated with Bentyl. The patient has a history of frequent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain associated with eating out and consuming alcohol. She reports that she has tried various remedies, including taking Bentyl up to four times daily and Zofran as needed. However, she notes that these remedies have not provided complete relief. The patient states that she has noticed a correlation between her symptoms and the amount of alcohol she consumes. She prefers Patron, but occasionally drinks other types of alcoholic beverages. She reports that she has tried reducing her alcohol intake, but this has not helped. The patient denies any recent changes in her diet or exercise routine. She reports that she has been experiencing nausea and abdominal pain, which has worsened since her last visit.

1. IBS with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting
Assessment: The patient has a history of IBS with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has tried Reglan in the past, which helped, but she has since developed tolerance to it. Her symptoms are triggered by high stress, poor eating habits, and poor sleeping habits.
Plan:
- Will continue to encourage dietary and lifestyle modifications.
- Will start neuromodulator such as elavil 25 milligrams at bedtime for IBS.
- Can use bentyl 20 milligrams as needed 30 to 45 minutes prior to eating out at a restaurant.
- Can also use zofran if needed.
- Encouraged her to reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption.
- Asked her to follow up in one month by emailing over MyChart regarding any side effects and issues, or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed.

Plan:
- Encourage dietary and lifestyle modifications, including increasing fiber intake and reducing sugar and fat consumption.
- Start elavil 25 mg QHS for IBS.
- Continue Bentyl 20 mg PO QID as needed for abdominal cramping.
- Use Zofran PRN for nausea.
- Follow up in one month via MyChart to monitor response to treatment and address any side effects or concerns.
Note_3:

- Start neuromodulator such as elavil 25 milligrams at bedtime for IBS.

- Use zofran if needed. 
- Reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up in one month by emailing over MyChart regarding any side effects and issues, or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed.

She takes Metformin 500mg once a day, but she believes she may have been prescribed 500mg twice a day previously. She has not been exercising for the past week due to stress. She denies any recent falls or head injuries.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Tension-type headache 
Assessment: The patient presents with a dull pain in the back of her head, flushing in her ears, and occasional dizziness. She reports that her symptoms are relieved with Tylenol and Advil, but return shortly after. Her symptoms began approximately 1 week ago, and she has experienced them previously. Differential diagnosis includes migraine, sinusitis, or occipital neuralgia. 
Plan: 
- Continue Tylenol and Advil PRN. 
- Add Flexeril 5mg Q6H for muscle relaxation. 
- Order CBC, Chem-10, and HbA1C. 
- Instruct the patient to monitor her blood sugar levels daily and bring the results to her follow-up appointment. 
- Recommend stress management techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or yoga. 
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 
Assessment: The patient has a history of DM2 and is currently taking Metformin 500mg PO BID. She has not been monitoring her blood sugars regularly due to stress. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 500mg PO BID. 
- Instruct the patient to monitor her blood sugar levels daily and bring the results to her follow-up appointment. 
- Set up an appointment in 4 weeks.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Headache 
Assessment: Tension type headache due to muscle tension in the neck and shoulder area, possibly exacerbated by working at the computer. No signs of stroke or bleeding in the brain. 
Plan: 
- Continue Tylenol PRN for pain relief. 
- Start Flexeril 5mg QHS for muscle relaxation. 
- Recommend frequent stretching and massage of the neck and shoulder areas. 
- If headache becomes more severe or suddenly worsens, or if fever develops, call the office immediately. 
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 
Assessment: Patient reports poor compliance with blood sugar monitoring and exercise. 
Plan: 
- Order hemoglobin A1C, CBC, and Chem-10. 
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID. 
- Instruct patient to check blood sugars daily and bring results to follow-up appointment. 
- Encourage regular exercise and healthy diet. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or earlier if headache does not improve.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Tension-type headache
Assessment: The patient presents with a tension-type headache, likely due to muscle tension in her neck and shoulders. She reports poor compliance with blood sugar monitoring and exercise.
Plan:
- Continue Tylenol PRN for pain relief.
- Prescribe Flexeril 5mg QHS for muscle relaxation.
- Order CBC, Chem-10, and HbA1C to monitor diabetes management.
- Encourage regular exercise and blood glucose monitoring.

2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II
Assessment: The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, which she has not been managing well. Her A1C is elevated.
Plan:
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID.
- Order HbA1C to monitor diabetes management.
- Encourage regular exercise and blood glucose monitoring.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or earlier if symptoms worsen.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Left upper extremity neuropathy suspected cervical radiculopathy, possible contribution of peripheral neuropathy
Assessment: The patient presented with left arm pain that is worse at night, which began approximately two weeks ago. He reports that the pain is starting in the hand and extending down the entire arm. He also reports weakness in his hand and difficulty grasping objects. Physical exam revealed positive bilateral biceps, triceps, and brachioradialis reflexes. Cervical X-ray shows significant disc degeneration at C5-C6 and C3-C4. MRI of the neck is needed to further evaluate the cause of his symptoms.
Plan:
- Order MRI of the neck.
- Continue gabapentin 300mg TID.
- Follow up with the patient after the MRI to determine his level of relief.

2. Neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration
Assessment: The patient presented with neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration. Physical exam revealed mildly restricted cervical extension, right and left lateral rotation, and spurling's maneuver was benign. Cervical X-ray showed significant lower lumbar facet arthropathy at C6-T1.
Plan:
- Set up Cervical MRI.
- Plan for cervical epidural injection once the MRI results are available.

3. Peripheral vascular disease (PVD)
Assessment: The patient reported history of PVD. Physical exam revealed decreased pulses in the left foot.
Plan:
- Continue to monitor the patient's pulses and assess for signs of progression.
- Consider referral to a specialist for further evaluation and management.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Left upper extremity neuropathy suspicious for cervical radicularopathy, possible contribution of peripheral neuropathy. 
Assessment: The patient presented with left arm pain, which began two weeks ago and is worse at night. He reports that the pain is similar to previous episodes, which resolved with ice packs. He denied any history of blood thinners. Physical exam revealed mildly restricted cervical extension, right and left lateral rotation, and spurling's maneuver is benign. Cervical X-ray showed significant disc degeneration at C5-C6, and to a lower extent C4-C5 and C3-C4. Lower lumbar facet arthropathy C6-T1 is difficult to visualize in the current X-rays. MRI of the neck is recommended to further evaluate the cause of his left upper extremity neuropathy. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain MRI of the neck. 
- Will set up for a cervical epidural injection, depending on the result of the MRI. 
- Continue twice daily gabapentin. 
- Follow up with the patient after the procedure to assess his level of relief.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Left upper extremity neuropathy suspicious for cervical radicularopathy, possible contribution of peripheral neuropathy
Assessment: The patient presented with left upper extremity neuropathy, which is suspected to be due to cervical radiculopathy. He also has history of peripheral neuropathy.
Plan:
- Will obtain MRI of the neck to further evaluate the cause of his neuropathy.
- Will consider starting gabapentin 300mg TID.
- Will refer the patient to physical therapy for exercises.

2. Neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration
Assessment: The patient has neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration.
Plan:
- Will obtain MRI of the neck to further evaluate the cause of his neck pain.
- Will consider starting gabapentin 300mg QHS.
- Will recommend heat or cold packs to the area.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Anxiety
Assessment: Patient reports improvement in anxiety symptoms, currently experiencing mild anxiety. No clear trigger identified.
Plan:
- Continue Buspirone 10mg QHS.
- Provide supportive therapy.
2. Breast lesions
Assessment: Patient reports persistent breast lesions despite treatment with progesterone. Exam revealed dense breasts without palpable masses. LFTs and TSH WNL.
Plan:
- Will monitor lesions closely.
- Consider referral to breast surgery for further evaluation and management.
3. Masked face thinning
Assessment: Patient reports weight loss over the past six months. Thinning of the masked face may be related to weight loss.
Plan:
- Encourage healthy diet and exercise.
- Monitor weight and body mass index (BMI) regularly.
4. Abnormal Pap smear history
Assessment: Patient has history of abnormal Pap smears in the past. Repeat Pap smear showed negative/negative.
Plan:
- Recommend annual pelvic exams.
5. Vaccine hesitancy
Assessment: Patient expresses concerns about COVID-19 vaccine safety.
Plan:
- Provide education about the benefits of vaccination.
- Offer resources to address vaccine hesitancy.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Anxiety:
Assessment: Patient reports improvement in anxiety symptoms, likely due to Buspar. However, she continues to experience anxiety attacks without clear trigger. She denies depression, suicidal ideation, or history of substance abuse.
Plan:
- Continue Buspar 10mg QHS.
- Consider psychiatric consultation if anxiety persists despite medication treatment.
2. Breast lump:
Assessment: Lumpectomy scar is healing well. No changes in size or shape of the lump compared to previous examination. Density of the breast tissue appears unchanged.
Plan:
- Monitor the breast lump closely.
- If the lump grows or changes, consider further diagnostic testing such as mammography or ultrasound.
3. Masked face:
Assessment: Thinning of the skin on the face may be related to age or sun exposure.
Plan:
- Recommend moisturizing the skin on the face regularly.
- Consider dermatologic consultation if the thinning of the skin on the face progresses or becomes painful.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 6 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Anxiety:
Assessment: Patient reports improvement in anxiety symptoms, likely due to Buspar. However, she continues to experience anxiety spikes without clear trigger. She denies any history of depression or suicidal ideation.
Plan:
- Continue Buspar 10mg QHS.
- Consider referral to psychiatry for further management of anxiety.

2. Breast lump:
Assessment: Patient has persistent breast lump despite two cycles of treatment with progesterone. Differential diagnosis includes benign breast disease (BBD), fibrocystic breast changes, or malignancy.
Plan:
- Recommend continued monitoring of breast lump with serial exams.
- If lump persists or grows, consider MRI or ultrasound to evaluate for malignancy.
- Refer to breast specialist for further evaluation and management.

3. Abnormal Pap smear:
Assessment: Patient has history of abnormal Pap smear in 2009, followed by normal Pap smears until 2019. She is currently due for another Pap smear.
Plan:
- Repeat Pap smear.
- If result remains abnormal, recommend colposcopy and biopsy.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up of breast lump and Pap smear results.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Routine follow-up with chronic medical conditions.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 61-year-old male who presents today for a routine follow-up with chronic medical conditions. He reports increased fatigue over the past several months, which he attributes to aging rather than disease. However, he states that he has noticed an increase in the amount of time it takes him to recover after engaging in strenuous activities such as cycling. He denies any changes in his hearing, vision, or balance. His current medications include vitamin D3 (5000 units on Sundays) and Clindamycin prior to dental procedures. The patient has received both COVID-19 vaccines (first dose on January 15th, 2021 and second dose on February 5th, 2021).

The patient reports a family history of heart problems, including his father and brother who died from heart attacks. He underwent an aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair on 1/20/2013. He is currently not being followed by cardiology.

The patient's physical exam reveals a purse lip breathing pattern and low exhalation phase. He is observed to have a 2-3 millimeter nodule on the right side of his testicle that feels separate from the epididymis. There is no hernia present. No wheezing is heard upon auscultation.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up of chronic medical conditions.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 61-year-old male who presents today for a routine follow-up of chronic medical conditions. He reports increased fatigue, but he attributes this to aging rather than disease progression. The patient continues to cycle 20-30 miles per day, but he feels exhausted afterwards. He also notes that his performance has decreased over the past year, requiring longer rest periods between rides. Additionally, the patient has noticed a small nodule on his right testicle. He denies wheezing or shortness of breath. His wife has never reported difficulty breathing or stopping breathing during sleep. The patient takes vitamin D supplements on Sundays (5000 units) and on the other six days (2000 units). He has received both doses of the COVID-19 vaccine.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Routine follow-up for chronic medical conditions.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 61-year-old male who presents today for a routine follow-up with chronic medical conditions. He reports increased fatigue, which he attributes to aging, but denies any changes in his exercise regimen. The patient continues to ride his bike, but he finds that he needs to rest more frequently during his rides. He typically rides 20 to 30 miles per ride, but he has noticed that he cannot complete longer distances without becoming exhausted. He also reports that his friend Tyler, who is older than him, often waits for him during their rides.

The patient has a history of aortic valve replacement and ascending aortic aneurysm repair performed on 1/22/2013. He is currently not followed by cardiology. His most recent blood work revealed elevated alkaline phosphatase (156), total cholesterol (247), HDL (66), LDL (166), and triglycerides (74). His TSH was within normal limits (2.68). His CBC was unremarkable. His vitamin D level was within normal limits (94).

On physical exam, the patient was noted to purse his lips while breathing. He was found to have low exhalation phase on exam. He also reported feeling more fatigued at the end of the day. He denied any wheezing or shortness of breath. His right testicular nodule was approximately two to three millimeters in size, and there was no hernia palpable.

The patient is due for a MMR vaccine, which will be administered today. He is also scheduled to receive the shingles vaccine next month. He has completed his COVID-19 vaccination series.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase Level
Assessment: The patient's recent lab work shows an elevated alkaline phosphatase level at 156. This could be related to his liver but most likely related to his bone health.
Plan:
- Order an alkaline phosphatase and again a GT.
- Follow up with the result and discuss further management.
2. Pursed Lip Breathing and Low Exhalation Phase
Assessment: The patient has been noted to purse his lips while breathing and has a low exhalation phase on exam. This may indicate obstructive sleep apnea or other underlying respiratory disease.
Plan:
- Perform pulmonary function tests (PFTs) today to further evaluate.
- Refer to pulmonology for further evaluation and treatment.
3. Right Testicular Nodule
Assessment: The patient has a nodule on his right testicle with two to three millimeters. There is no hernia palpable.
Plan:
- Recommend reaching out to urology for a possible ultrasound.
4. Fatigue
Assessment: The patient reports increased fatigue at the end of the day. He denies any depressive symptoms.
Plan:
- Discuss exercise habits and encourage regular exercise.
- Consider referral to sleep specialist for obstructive sleep apnea evaluation.
5. MMV Vaccine
Assessment: The patient is overdue for MMR vaccine.
Plan:
- Administer MMR vaccine today.
6. Shingles Vaccine
Assessment: The patient is fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and is due for the shingles vaccine.
Plan:
- Administer the shingles vaccine next month.
Follow-Up Instructions:
- Return for a follow-up in one year for a wellness visit, sooner if needed.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

[doctor] good afternoon , beverly . good to see you .
[patient] nice to see you too .
[doctor] so , i know my nurse told you a little bit about dax . um , now , if you do n't mind , i'd like to tell dax a little bit about you .
[patient] go for it .
[doctor] great . um , beverly's a 24 year old female patient , and i know you have a history of type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure . correct ?
[patient] yep .
[doctor] okay . so , you're here today for your yearly exam . have n't seen you in a year . how're you doing ?
[patient] i've been doing well . i began working in a bakery this summer which has been super fun. i have really been enjoying working there, but i find myself, since i am so close to so many delicious treats, snacking a lot during shifts and eating a lot more desserts than i normally would.
[doctor] okay , so , that brings me to your diabetes . so , how have your blood sugars been ?
[patient] uh , not so good .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] so , they've been up and down because of my diet , i think , because i've been taking my medication as prescribed . um , so , i have n't missed anything there , but my diet has been pretty bad lately .
[doctor] pretty bad lately ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] okay . and , that's really the only thing that's different is your diet , pretty much ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] and , that's because of the new job and all that ?
[patient] yeah. it has been really challenging to resist the temptation. 
[doctor] it's hard to ignore those desserts , are n't they ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] no willpower like me ?
[patient] no , no willpower .
[doctor] okay . all right . and , and then , um , i know you've had high blood pressure , hypertension . how is , how have your blood sugars been ? have you been checking them ?
[patient] so , my blood pressure's been good . um , despite my , um , my diabetes levels being up and down .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] so , that's been good .
[doctor] okay , so , your blood pressures have been normal . you've been sleeping well ?
[patient] yep , getting a full eight hours .
[doctor] no concerns about hurting yourself or anything like that ?
[patient] no .

[doctor] okay , good . okay , and i know my , um , nurse did a review of systems . other than what we've talked about so far , is there anything else that you needed to add ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] good . so , pretty much status quo except for those things that we've been working on , right ?
[patient] yep .
[doctor] okay , good . all right . well , let me do a quick physical exam , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay , squeeze my finger here . good . can you feel me touch out here ?
[patient] yep .
[doctor] okay . and , can you feel me touch you down here ?
[patient] yep .
[doctor] okay . no swelling . push your leg out . good . pull it back . mm-hmm . go . good . okay . so , on my exam , um , essentially , your exam is normal . your , um , heart is regular . you do have that grade 2 , um , systolic ejection fraction back ejection murmur that you , um , that we've heard in the past . okay ? so , um , we definitely know that's there . that's unchanged , okay ? um , your lungs are clear . um , your grips are equal . neurovascular's intact . you do n't have any carotid bruits in your neck , no thyromegaly . no edema . um , pulses are good , so essentially , your exam is , is essentially normal . let's take a look at some of your lab work , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] hey , dragon , show me the hemoglobin a1c . okay , so , blood sugars have been elevated . your hemoglobin a1c is elevated as well , so that tells me your blood sugars have been a little bit out of control . you're still taking the metformin , correct ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] okay , and you take that twice a day ?
[patient] yep .
[doctor] okay . um , uh , hey , dragon ? show me the vital signs . okay , good news here is your blood pressure's good . everything , um , there is fine . so , um , so , my assessment is , is , um , your first problem is diabetes . it's a little out of control . we'd like that hemoglobin a1c to be under seven , um , at least . you know , preferably , under six .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] so , um , uh , i'm not gon na change your medication . i think this is diet related , so i want you to try to cut down on the snacking and additional sweets , okay ?
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] and , i want you to check your blood sugars in the morning . i want you to call them in in about two weeks so we know what your first , um , fasting blood sugar was in the morning , and then , we'll come back and see you in about two months and see if everything has straightened out . if it has n't , then we'll talk about adding another medication , okay ?
[patient] okay .
[doctor] your second problem is your hypertension . that seems to be relatively stable . i want you to stay on your current medication . you're on li- lisinopril 10 mg once a day . just stay right on that medication . no changes at this point . seems to be doing well , okay ?
[patient] okay .

[doctor] good . anything else i can do for you today ?
[patient] no . that's it .
[doctor] good . come with me , we'll get you checked out .
[patient] thank you .
[doctor] hey , dragon ? finalize the note .

Yearly exam.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (A1C 7.9%) 
Assessment: Elevated A1C. Patient reports poor dietary compliance due to new job. No other concerning symptoms. 
Plan: 
- Will continue Metformin 500mg BID. 
- Encourage healthier dietary habits. 
- Repeat A1C in 2 weeks. If A1C remains elevated, consider additional therapy such as sulfonylurea or insulin. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is normal. Continue Lisinopril 10mg Qday. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Check blood pressure in 2 weeks. 
- Return to clinic in 2 months to reassess blood pressure and blood glucose control.
Note_2:

1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
Assessment: Elevated A1C, poor dietary control. 
Plan: 
- Will continue Metformin 500mg BID. 
- Patient will monitor FBS in AM and call in results in 2 weeks. 
- If FSBS remain elevated, will consider addition of another medication. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Continue Lisinopril 10mg Qday.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (A1C >7%)
Assessment: Elevated A1C level suggests poor glucose control. Patient reports increased snacking and dessert consumption due to her new job. No changes in medications.
Plan:
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID.
- Encourage healthy dietary habits.
- Check fasting blood sugar in 2 weeks and follow up in 2 months. If blood sugar remains elevated, consider adding another medication.
2. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure is currently well controlled.
Plan:
- Continue Lisinopril 10mg Qday.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 months for follow-up.

Dialogue:
[doctor] good afternoon alexis i understand you're having some issues with your hand
[patient] yes i sit at the keyboard all day long and recently i've been having some numbness and tingling in my right hand
[doctor] okay how long has that been going on
[patient] i do n't know probably on and off for six months but over the last month or so it's been a little more persistent
[doctor] okay okay and when does that numbness and tingling do you get a lot of pain with it first let me ask that question
[patient] some pain
[doctor] some pain
[patient] mostly when i'm actually typing on the keyboard is when i experience the pain
[doctor] okay
[patient] but the numbness and tingling is all the time now
[doctor] okay and when you get this pain what makes it better is it stopping and just resting for a while or do you take medications or try other
[patient] i've been taking ibuprofen so ibuprofen and seem like not typing on the keyboard helps the most
[doctor] okay
[patient] the other thing that makes it hurt is my mouse
[doctor] your mouth okay
[patient] wow
[doctor] yeah when you're moving that around okay
[patient] yeah
[doctor] does this pain ever wake you up in the middle of the night or the pain or the tingling
[patient] no
[doctor] no okay
[patient] not affecting my sleep hmmm
[doctor] okay so and you're using motrin for for ibuprofen for for the pain well let me go ahead and take a take a look here at your is it both hands or just your right hand
[patient] mostly my right hand
[doctor] mostly your right hand okay so let's go ahead and take a look at that right hand when i bend your wrist does that cause any pain
[patient] yes
[doctor] it does okay and so you do have some pain on extension and if you pull your your hand wrist up towards you does that cause the pain also
[patient] yes
[doctor] yeah okay so you do have pain on flexion and extension and when i touch the fingertips here now you said you had some numbness in your thumb and your index finger and a little bit in your your middle finger the other two fingers they feel okay or do you think that there is different than the other hand
[patient] yeah for some reason it really is just that the thumb the pointer in the middle finger that i experience the most symptoms with
[doctor] okay
[patient] not why that is
[doctor] okay so i i want you to grip my hands here and just squeeze tight okay so you do have a a little bit of a less grip strength on the right and that's typical that we would see with this type of pain and and numbness that you have going on now i want you to turn your arm over for me and i'm gon na touch on or tap on the inside of your wrist or or forearm and when i do that i can see your face you're grimacing so that that that must cause that shooting pain yeah okay so you do have a positive tinel's sign so in alexis what i think is going on is that you have a a carpal tunnel syndrome and we see that frequent
[patient] i was afraid of
[doctor] yeah you see this frequently but people who are doing data entry spend a lot of time on keyboards or you know some a lotta manufacturing people who do a repetitive procedure again and again will get that type of pain so here is my plan i'd like to put you in a splint and it's it's it's kind of a wrist splint i would like you to wear that at night that will help with that i want you to continue with the ibuprofens but i would like you to go up to six hundred milligrams four times a day and
[patient] okay
[doctor] we're gon na do that now i am going to order some a a outpatient test called an emg where we look at that nerve conduction study in that wrist and that's really what's happening here is you've got some thickening in the the in the wrist and the the the membranes of the wrist that are just pressing down and just compressing some of those nerves any other questions for me for now if that test comes back positive and we'll talk about that later on your next visit if it comes back positive we may have to do we're gon na stick with conservative treatment first but we may consider some surgery where i can go in and release that impingement on your nerves through your wrist it's a simple outpatient procedure and then i think you would feel better how does that sound
[patient] that sounds like a good plan i was hoping maybe i could get some relief with some therapy rather than having to go to surgery so i like that plan very much
[doctor] yeah we'll start with the the wrist splint and once i get the nerve conduction studies that will give me another idea whether or not i need to send you some physical therapy in addition or if we need to go directly to surgery but that will all hinge on that nerve conduction test do you so do you have any further questions
[patient] no that's great thank you so much
[doctor] thank you very much

SUBJECTIVE 
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Right hand numbness, tingling, and pain. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right hand numbness, tingling, and pain. The patient reports he has been experiencing these symptoms for approximately six months, with increased frequency over the past month. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the right hand. He states his pain is worse when he types on the keyboard and uses his mouse. He takes ibuprofen for pain relief. He describes the pain as sharp and burning. Physical examination reveals weakness in the right hand, particularly in the thumb, index finger, and middle finger. Tinel's sign is positive.
Note_2:

Numbness, tingling, pain in right hand. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

He reports that he sits at the keyboard all day long and has been experiencing numbness and tingling in his right hand for approximately 6 months. The numbness and tingling are constant and have been getting worse over the past month. He denies any history of trauma to the right hand. He reports that the pain is mostly when he is typing on the keyboard and sometimes when he uses his mouse. The pain is described as aching and sharp. It is exacerbated by movement of the hand and wrist. He has tried ibuprofen and Motrin with some relief. He denies any pain that awakens him from sleep.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Carpal tunnel syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with numbness, tingling, pain in her right hand, particularly in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome. She has positive Tinel's sign and weak grip strength on the right side. 
Plan: 
- Will place patient in a wrist splint at night. 
- Continue ibuprofen 600mg QID. 
- Order EMG to assess nerve conduction study in the wrist. 
2. Pain management 
Assessment: The patient experiences pain with typing on the keyboard and with holding her mouse. 
Plan: 
- Recommend patient to use ibuprofen as needed for pain. 
3. Possible sleep disorder 
Assessment: The patient denies any waking up in the middle of the night due to pain or numbness.

Vision problems.

The patient is a pleasant male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of vision problems. He reports experiencing difficulty adjusting to dim environments, such as restaurants, for several months. The vision problems began approximately 3-4 months ago and have progressively worsened. The patient describes his vision as being blurry when he reads in dimly lit areas, particularly when he eats out at fancy restaurants. Additionally, he notes that straight lines appear wavy to him, similar to the way paneling with dark grooves appears wavy. The patient states that these symptoms occur in both eyes. He denies any recent changes in hearing, headaches, dizziness, or vertigo. The patient continues to smoke cigarettes despite efforts to quit due to the difficulties he experiences in quitting. His blood pressure medication has been noncompliant as well.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular Age Related Macular Degeneration (wet AMD)
Assessment: The patient presented with decreased vision, particularly in low light environments, and straight line distortion. He also reported difficulty quitting smoking. Diagnostic tests revealed Drusen deposits under the RPE, subretinal fluid accumulation, and choroidal neovascular membrane. Fluorescein angiography showed focal area of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular AMD.
Plan:
- Will refer patient to ophthalmology for further evaluation and treatment.
- Will initiate Lucent injection therapy once per month.
2. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient reported not taking his blood pressure medication for a while.
Plan:
- Will encourage the patient to restart taking his blood pressure medication as prescribed.
3. Smoking cessation
Assessment: The patient reported difficulty quitting smoking.
Plan:
- Will counsel the patient on the importance of quitting smoking.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.

Assessment: Patient reports difficulty quitting smoking.
Plan:
- Continue counseling and support for smoking cessation.

- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up and injection.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right ankle sprain 
Assessment: The patient presents with right ankle pain, swelling, and bruising after falling on her right ankle while taking out the trash. She has tenderness to palpation of the anterior lateral soft tissue and positive for ecchymosis or bruising over the lateral malleolus. There is no laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress. Neurovascular exam of the right foot shows brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds, strong dorsalis pedis pulse, and normal sensation to light touch. X-ray of the right ankle showed no fracture. 
Plan: 
- Continue to elevate the leg when seated. 
- Ice the ankle. 
- Provide air cast and crutches. 
- Recommend nsaids or ibuprofen as needed for pain relief. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up in 2 weeks.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS)
Assessment: The patient presents with left and right knee pain for 6 months, with exacerbation with squatting and walking up and down stairs. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays show no fractures or osteoarthritis. MRI showed mild degenerative changes in the patellofemoral joint.
Plan: 
- Continue ibuprofen or Aleve as needed for pain relief. 
- Recommend physical therapy to improve lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct running mechanics.
2. Possible overuse injury
Assessment: The patient is an avid runner who has been experiencing knee pain for 6 months. She reports pain with squatting and walking up and down stairs. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays show no fractures or osteoarthritis. MRI showed mild degenerative changes in the patellofemoral joint.
Plan: 
- Encourage the patient to reduce her running intensity and frequency. 
- Consider referral to sports medicine specialist for further evaluation and management.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with left and right knee pain, particularly with squatting, climbing stairs, and running. She has a history of patellofemoral pain syndrome and has tried various treatments including ibuprofen, Aleve, and Tylenol. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays of both knees show no fractures or osteoarthritis. MRI showed patellofemoral joint degenerative changes. 
Plan: 
- Continue taking ibuprofen or Aleve as needed for pain relief. 
- Recommend physical therapy to improve lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct incorrect running mechanics. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with left and right knee pain, particularly with squatting and climbing stairs, associated with tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays of both knees were reviewed and showed no fractures or osteoarthritis. MRI was also reviewed and showed no evidence of osteoarthritis or meniscal tears. Physical exam revealed tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. Differential diagnosis includes patellofemoral pain syndrome, chondromalacia patellae, and tibial stress syndrome. 
Plan: 
- Continue taking ibuprofen or Aleve as needed for pain relief. 
- Recommend physical therapy to improve lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct incorrect running mechanics. 
- Encourage the patient to avoid heavy lifting, squatting, and prolonged sitting. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 40mg Qday. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 3 weeks for follow-up.

- Continue lifestyle modifications.

- Will also prescribe Flexeril 10mg QHS for muscle relaxation.

Plan: 
- Continue current treatment regimen, including diet and exercise. 
- Recommend frequent monitoring of blood sugar levels. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for repeat evaluation of pain and diabetes management.
