Physical exam showed limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness to the greater tuberosity of the humerus, and brisk capillary refill of less than three seconds. Neurovascular exam of the right arm showed equal and bilateral response to sensation and touch. MRI of the right shoulder was ordered to rule out other causes of shoulder pain.
Plan:
- Refer to physical therapy for six to eight weeks.
- Continue to take NSAID (tylenol) for pain.
- Follow up in two weeks to reassess and make additional treatment plans.

[doctor] hey angela how are you
[patient] i'm good how are you
[doctor] i'm good so i see we are here you had a recent diagnosis of stage three nonsmol cell lung cancer and so we are following up on your neo adevant chemotherapy so you can you tell me how you're doing today
[patient] yeah you know i'm i'm doing okay i have a little bit of some shortness of breath that i noticed over the weekend and you know i i'm i considered myself pretty active before this i would walk my dog around the block and now i i ca n't even walk you know down the street without being short of breath
[doctor] okay yeah yeah i mean that's that's definitely understandable it says you had a four point four centimeter left upper lobe nodule in there so it's kinda big but that's understandable and we're doing the chemo to try to reduce that that that tumor that you do have so how often do you normally run with your dogs
[patient] i mean i would i would take them for i would normally take them for like mile long walks everyday and just this weekend i could only walk down to the end of the street i had to have my husband take the dog fit walk
[doctor] man okay what kind of dog do you have
[patient] i have a dobrman
[doctor] yeah they are pretty active that makes sense alright so have you been coughing have you had any phlegm
[patient] i've been having a dry cough no phlegm
[doctor] okay have you noticed any fever
[patient] no fever
[doctor] no fever alright what about any other symptoms like any body aches any sore throat sinus pain
[patient] well i mean now that you mentioned it like every time i swallow it hurts it does n't feel like i have a cold because it hurts down here more in my chest but every time i swallow it it's really painful
[doctor] okay so when you are swallowing i know some of my patients feel this do you feel like the food is getting stuck
[patient] no the food is not getting stuck it just hurts
[doctor] okay what about when you're you're taking liquids are you able to take in both hydrocort liquids
[patient] i mean i definitely feel like over the weekend i have n't been taking it as much because it hurt so much but i i am able to i am able to drink and i've been taking ensure and things like that i had a milk shake
[doctor] okay that's that's that's that's good yeah we we definitely want you to to take in as much liquid as possible best especially since you're on the chemotherapy and the radiation just so you wo n't get dehydrated because that will make you feel a lot worse if you are dehydrated okay so on a on a mental emotional standpoint i know you said you have your husband with you how you doing with that you have the support that you need you need to speak to me though
[patient] it's very helpful you know as you can understand i'm just like devastated when i got this diagnosis and i'm just i'm just trying to figure everything out and but he is very good and my daughter is is very helpful too and i you know i think for the most part i'm very fortunate to have them
[doctor] okay so how how are you feeling on your chemo see you're on a combination of sysplatin and a topicide you had your last dose a few days ago any nausea any fatigue from that
[patient] i was a little nauseated and tired but i took the zofran that you prescribed and that seemed to help and you know i i got some rest it's it's it's been okay
[doctor] okay that's good so let me do a quick physical exam on you just gon na check your vitals here so your vitals are normal your pulse ox is okay so everything's good with that so i'm gon na feel your neck on your neck exam i do n't appreciate any cervical lymphadenopathy no subclavicular adenopathy your heart exam regular rate and rhythm no murmur your lung exam so i do notice some crackles in your lungs bilaterally that's just a faint sound we hear when you take a deep breath so that could mean you have some fluid in there and that is to be expected due to your lung cancer diagnosis so i'm gon na look at your skin exam so on your skin exam on your chest i do see some erythema on the anterior aspect of your chest on the left side and that could be due to that radiation sometimes patients do get a radiation burn and it's it'll get better with time especially once you're done with the the radiation treatment and on your extremity it there is no lower extremity edema in your legs so prior to coming to see me you did get a chest x-ray it looks like you do have mild radiation umitis that means you have inflammation of your lungs due to the radiation so let's talk a little bit about my assessment and plan for you so your first diagnosis you know is is the lung cancer so we are gon na continue you on that chemo regimen on that you do have continue on that that current radiation doses i think you're on forty five grade yep you're on that and then when the when the regimen's complete we'll do some more testing and hopefully we can see a resection of that tumor so that has just gotten little smaller and we can go inside and and take it out so for your second diagnosis the radiation pneumonitis i'm gon na prescribe you a low dose steroid prednisone forty milligrams one tablet a day for five days have you been on on a steroids before
[patient] no i've only ever heard bad things about them they make people jittery and gain weight
[doctor] i mean and and i for you that's that that's for patients that you know who are on them for a a long period of time right you're only gon na be on it for five days that should n't affect you too bad you might feel when you coming off of it after the five days a few muscle aches other than that you should be fine you should n't really experience much weight gain other other than not not much at all since you're only on on it for five days so but that's gon na help you reduce some of the inflammation in your lungs help you breathe better so we can continue the radiation treatment because we definitely need to do that because our most important thing right now is to try to decrease the size of that tumor okay and then for your third issue the oddy ophagia or it come terms the painful swallowing right you said you had that from the from the radiation so that's from the inflammation of your lungs that's kinda creeping up to your esophagus that's why you're you're feeling that pain so i'm gon na prescribe you a lidocaine squishy and swallow you can do that four times a day and so you'll do it and you'll be able to eat immediately afterwards because it would do some of that pain free from swallowing and that will help you taking liquids and food because we definitely need you well off it and and and hydrated while you're going through this cancer therapy okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright so do you have any questions for me
[patient] no
[doctor] alright so we will get you those medications those prescriptions and then we will see you back in two weeks
[patient] okay great thank you
[doctor] thanks

Right ankle pain after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right ankle pain after a fall. The patient reports falling while taking out the trash last night, resulting in a right ankle injury. She denies any prior history of ankle injuries. She states she has been able to walk on the affected ankle with a little bit of weight bearing. Her pain is described as a throbbing pain, constant in nature, with warmth to the touch. She has tried icing and taking ibuprofen without relief. She denies any numbness or tingling in her foot.

Physical examination reveals ecchymosis on the lateral aspect of the right malleolus associated with swelling. There is tenderness to palpation of the anterior and lateral aspects of the soft tissue. No laxity on the anterior drawer test. No bony tenderness on palpation of the foot. Neurovascular examination of the right foot reveals a capillary refill of less than three seconds, strong DP pulse, and intact sensation to light touch. X-ray of the ankle shows no fracture or bony abnormalities.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Right ankle sprain
Assessment: Patient presents with right ankle pain, edema, and ecchymosis following a fall. No fracture or bone abnormalities seen on X-ray. Exam shows tenderness to palpation of the anterior laterally in the soft tissue and no laxity on the anterior drawer and inversion stress. Neurovascular exam is intact to light touch.
Plan:
- Will provide an air cast to stabilize the ankle.
- Will provide crutches.
- Instruct patient to keep the leg elevated when seated and ice the ankle five times a day for 20 minutes each.
- Advised patient to stay off the leg for about one to two days and then gradually increase activity as tolerated.

2. Pain control
Assessment: Patient reports pain level of 6 out of 10.
Plan:
- Will prescribe acetaminophen 500mg Q8h PRN pain.
- If pain persists, may consider alternative analgesic medications.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.
- Contact the office if pain continues beyond 2 weeks or if new complaints develop.

- Instruct the patient to stay off the leg for about 1-2 days and then gradually increase activity as tolerated.
- Anticipate recovery within 2-3 weeks.
- If pain persists beyond 2 weeks or worsens, refer for MRI.

[patient] no not yet i heard about it though i might have to make a trip once my foot heals
[doctor] alright that sounds good now just out of curiosity can you rate your pain for me right now zero being none ten being the worst pain you've ever been in your life
[patient] eleven out of ten
[doctor] okay and then have you experienced any numbness or tingling of that foot since the incident
[patient] yeah the whole foot is numb
[doctor] okay
[patient] but been now for a long time
[doctor] okay i'm gon na do a quick physical exam now your vitals look good and i would like to do a focused exam of your right foot the there is some bruising on the bottom part of your foot and on the top part as well and i do appreciate the associated swelling and i also recognize that you do have tenderness to palpation for midfoot now for your neurovascular exam of your right foot your capillary refill is brisk in less than three seconds i do note a strong bounding dorsalis pedis pulse with motor and sensation is intact for that foot i also like to call out the fact that it matches bilaterally which is important i'm gon na go ahead and review the diagnostic imaging results so we did a x-ray of that right foot and i do notice dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and presence of bony fragments so let me tell you a little bit about my assessment and plan now your right foot pain is due to a lisfranc fracture which is a fracture to your second metatarsal bone and the top of your foot this is where the metatarsals meet those cuboids okay so it where the bones come together in your foot now there are a lot of ligaments in your foot so i do want to order an mri just to assess if there is any injuries to those ligaments now based on your exam and looking at the x-ray you're most likely going to need surgery now the reason why this is important is if we have poor bone alignment or ligament healing you can this can lead to losing the arch in your foot you could becoming flat-footed and also developing arthritis now what's gon na be key here is the surgery is going to allow those bones and ligaments to heal properly we are going to put them back into place using plates and screws now the key thing is going to be it's going to be outpatient surgery so it's going to be same day i'll see you in the morning and then you'll be discharged home that evening and we will do a follow-up i wan na see you in twenty four hours post procedure but then i'll see you again in two weeks you're gon na be in a cast and i'm gon na have you use crutches you're not gon na be able to weight-bear on that foot for six to eight weeks what we'll do is we'll advance your ambulating gradually based on how you heal and based on how you tolerate the procedure i know i have covered a lot of material quickly but this is really gon na be the best course of action for you to have a good outcome now do you have any questions come answers concerns before i have the nurse come in finish the paperwork and get you set up for your procedure which we are going to do tomorrow if you're agreeable to that

1. Lisfranc fracture 
Assessment: The patient presents with right foot pain, swelling, and bruising. X-ray shows dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a three millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and presence of bony fragments. - Patient will be non-weight bearing on the right foot for 6-8 weeks. 
- Will advance ambulation gradually based on healing and tolerance.

- Refer to physical therapy for stretching and strengthening exercises. 
2. Diabetes mellitus type 2 
Assessment: Hemoglobin A1C (HgbA1c) 7.1%. The patient has been compliant with diet and exercise. Continue Metformin 500mg BID. 
Plan: 
- Order HgbA1c again in 2 weeks. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Swelling in legs. Stopped Norvasc and started Hydrochlorothiazide 10mg Qday. 
Plan: 
- Check CBC, BMP, EKG, Chest X-ray. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Bilateral Carpal Tunnel Syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with numbness, tingling, and pain in his fingers and wrist, which has been progressive over several months. He denies any trauma or injury to the area. Examination reveals decreased grip strength and sensation in the left hand, along with positive Tinel's sign on both sides. 
Plan: 
- Order EMG study to confirm diagnosis. 
- Activity modification: Avoid heavy lifting and repetitive motion activities. 
- Wear wrist splint to support the wrist and reduce pressure on the median nerve. 
- Take ibuprofen 600mg Q8H for pain relief. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment and consider further interventions, including surgery, if necessary.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Bilateral Carpal Tunnel Syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with numbness, tingling, and pain in his fingers, particularly in the thumb and pointer finger, as well as weakness in his left hand. He has a positive Tinel's sign on both sides. His clinical exam and history suggest a diagnosis of bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome.
Plan: 
- Order EMG to confirm the diagnosis. 
- Activity modification: Avoid repetitive activities such as landscaping and heavy lifting. 
- Wear a wrist splint. 
- Take ibuprofen 600mg every 6 hours. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks. 

2. Yard Work Injury 
Assessment: The patient has a history of yard work injury. He reports pain and numbness in his hands and wrist. He is concerned about losing his job due to his condition. 
Plan: 
- Provide education on proper techniques for landscaping and gardening. 
- Consider referral to occupational therapy for ergonomic training. 
- Discuss the possibility of lightening the workload or delegating tasks to others. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Bilateral Carpal Tunnel Syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with numbness, tingling, and pain in his fingers and wrist, which began gradually over several months. He has a positive Tinel's sign on both sides. His clinical exam and history suggest bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome. 
Plan: 
- Order EMG study. 
- Activity modification (delegating tasks). 
- Wear wrist splint. 
- Ibuprofen 600mg Q6H. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks. 
2. Yard Work-related Injury 
Assessment: The patient works as a landscaper and experiences frequent repetitive strain injuries. 
Plan: 
- Provide education on proper lifting techniques and ergonomics. 
- Consider referral to physical therapy. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks.

- Will instruct the patient to avoid weight bearing on the left foot until the surgery.

Assessment: Patient has history of CAD, s/p PCI x2 with DES to LAD and RCA. He reports feeling better with medications. However, he is concerned about taking multiple medications and feels dizzy when standing up quickly. 
Plan:

- Will continue current medications: Aspirin, Brilinta, Metoprolol, Crestor, Fish Oil. 
- Will obtain A1c and lipid profile. 
- Will discuss importance of following up with his Nephrologist.

Plan: 
- Will contact Dr. ___ to schedule an appointment.

Plan: 
- Will obtain repeat A1c. 
- Will refer patient to Dietitian for diabetic education. 
4. Depression 
Assessment: Patient expresses feelings of loneliness and hopelessness after his heart attack. 
Plan: 
- Will refer patient to Psychiatry for evaluation and treatment of depression.

- Follow up in 1-2 weeks.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Kidney Stone
Assessment: Patient has a history of recurrent kidney stones, currently presenting with severe left-sided back pain, low-grade fever, and hematuria. Physical exam reveals CVA tenderness and rebound tenderness over the right flank. Urinalysis shows leukocytes and bacteria. 
Plan: 
- Will start oxycodone 5 mg Q6H PRN for pain management. 
- Will provide patient with a strainer to collect his urine for analysis. 
- Will refer patient to urology for further evaluation and treatment. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure is well controlled on current regimen. 
Plan: 
- Continue Norvasc 2.5mg Qday. 
3. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2
Assessment: Patient's A1C is elevated at 7.3%, indicating poor blood sugar control. He reports taking Metformin daily and checking his blood sugar before each meal. However, his recent glucose level was found to be >300. 
Plan: 
- Refer patient to nutrition to a dietitian for education on healthy eating habits and meal planning. 
- Continue Metformin 500mg Qday.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Kidney Stone 
Assessment: Patient presents with severe left back pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. She has a history of kidney stones and this episode appears to be her third episode. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation of the abdomen, CVA tenderness on the right flank, and mild costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows positive leukocytes, negative nitrites, and moderate bacteria. 
Plan: 
- Will start oxycodone 5mg Q6H PRN for pain. 
- Refer to urology for further evaluation and management. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is elevated (SBP 140-150mmHg). 
Plan: 
- Continue Norvasc 2.5mg PO Qday. 
3. Diabetes Mellitus Type II 
Assessment: A1C is 7.3% and FSG is 189. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 500mg PO BID. 
- Refer to nutritionist for dietary counseling.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Kidney Stone 
Assessment: The patient has a history of recurrent kidney stones, current presentation consistent with another episode. She is experiencing severe pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation of the abdomen and CVA tenderness on the right flank. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain an ultrasound to confirm the presence of a kidney stone. 
- Will start oxycodone 5 mg Q6H PRN for pain. 
- Will provide a strainer to collect her urine and monitor for passage of the stone. 
- Refer to Urology for further management. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Continue Norvasc 2.5mg daily. 
3. Diabetes 
Assessment: A1C is elevated at 7.3%. Patient reports taking Metformin 500mg daily and checking blood sugar before each meal. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 500mg daily. 
- Refer to Nutrition for dietary counseling. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Kidney Stone
Assessment: Patient presents with right sided flank pain, radiation to groin, nausea, vomiting, and increased urinary frequency. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation over the right side of the abdomen and right lower quadrant. CT scan shows a stone measuring 0.5 cm located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.
Plan:
- Recommend pushing fluids to help facilitate passage of the stone.
- Prescribe Oxycodone 5mg Q6H PRN pain and Tylenol between doses for breakthrough pain.
- Continue using a strainer to collect the stone.
- Order BMP, Urinalysis, and Urine Culture.
- Follow up in 1-2 weeks. If the stone has not passed, consider lithotripsy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right renal colic due to nephrolithiasis 
Assessment: Patient presents with right flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. He has a history of kidney stones in his family. Physical exam shows tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant. CT scan shows a stone measuring 0.5 cm in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis. 
Plan: 
- Will recommend pushing fluids to facilitate urination and passage of the stone. 
- Prescribe oxycodone 5mg Q6H PRN pain and Tylenol for breakthrough pain. 
- Continue using a strainer. 
- Order BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture. 
- Follow up in 1-2 weeks to check progress. If stone has not passed, may consider lithotripsy.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right MCL strain/tear 
Assessment: Patient presented with right knee pain, swelling, and ecchymosis after playing basketball. Physical exam revealed tenderness to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, positive varus and valgus tests, and slight swelling, redness, and ecchymosis. X-ray showed no fracture or bony abnormality. Plan: 
- Continue Tylenol PRN for pain relief. 
- Prescribed Meloxicam 15mg Qday for pain and swelling. 
- Knee immobilizer and stay off of the affected leg for 2 weeks. 
- Schedule MRI for further evaluation. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure was slightly elevated (SBP 140-150). He is currently taking Norvasc 5mg daily. Plan: 
- Increase Norvasc dosage to 10mg daily. 
3. Diabetes 
Assessment: Patient's A1C was 7.2%. He reports intermittent fasting glucose monitoring and occasional skipping Metformin due to stomach upset. Plan: 
- Consult nutrition for education on healthy dietary habits. 
- Adjust Metformin dosage as needed. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee MCL strain/tear 
Assessment: Patient presents with right knee pain, swelling, and ecchymosis following a sports injury while playing basketball. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, positive varus and valgus tests, and mild swelling and redness. X-ray of the right knee revealed no fractures or bony abnormalities. Plan: 
- Continue Tylenol for pain relief. 
- Prescribe Meloxicam 15mg Qday for pain and swelling. 
- Provide knee immobilizer and instruct patient to remain nonweightbearing for the next few weeks. 
- Order MRI of the right knee to further evaluate the injury. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is slightly elevated (140/80). Plan: 
- Increase Norvasc dosage to 10mg Qday. 
3. Diabetes 
Assessment: A1C is 7.2%. Plan: 
- Consult nutrition to improve dietary habits. 
- Monitor blood glucose levels regularly. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS)
Assessment: The patient presented with bilateral knee pain, particularly with squatting and descending stairs, associated with crepitus in the knees. Physical exam revealed bilateral tenderness to palpation of the retinaculum, positive patellar grind test, and limited range of motion in flexion. X-ray showed no fracture or osteoarthritis. Differential diagnoses include osteoarthritis, meniscal tear, and ligamentous injury. However, given the absence of these findings on x-ray, PFPS is the most likely diagnosis.
Plan:
- Continue ibuprofen or anti-inflammatory as needed for pain relief.
- Recommend physical therapy to improve lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct incorrect running mechanics.
- Follow up with the patient in 2 weeks to reassess their progress.
- Encourage the patient to take it easy from running for now.

- Continue ibuprofen or anti-inflammatory as needed for pain relief.
- Referral to physical therapy for lower extremity exercises and correction of incorrect running mechanics.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chronic lumbar back pain 
Assessment: Based on the patient's history, physical exam, MRI findings, and musculoskeletal ultrasound findings, his symptoms are most likely due to a herniated disk at L4-L5 level with radiculopathy. He may also have a component of fibromyalgia given his report of diffuse pain throughout his body. He denied any recent trauma or injury. His exam shows midline tenderness on the L4-L5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness when he bends forward. There is decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome, and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical. The patient's pain is worst with lumbar flexion and extension and with raising his leg. Supine straight leg test is positive.
Plan: 
- Will perform a spinal injection with a strong anti-inflammatory medication called a corticosteroid. 
- Will refer him to physical therapy. 
- Will consider starting a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) such as naproxen or ibuprofen. 
- Will discuss the possibility of surgery if the patient continues to experience pain despite conservative management. 
2. Tobacco use 
Assessment: The patient reports using cigarettes in the past. He denies current smoking. 
Plan: 
- Encourage smoking cessation. 
3. Obesity 
Assessment: The patient has gained approximately 80 pounds in the past year. 
Plan: 
- Discuss diet and exercise with the patient. 
4. Scoliosis 
Assessment: The patient reports scoliosis in his fourth cousin. 
Plan: 
- Refer the patient to a specialist for further evaluation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chronic lumbar back pain 
Assessment: Based on the patient's history, physical examination, and MRI findings, his chronic lumbar back pain is likely due to a herniated disk at L4-L5 level with radiculopathy. The patient reports that he has tried physical therapy, injections, and pain medications without relief. He also reports a history of smoking. 
Plan: 
- Will perform a spinal injection with a strong anti-inflammatory medication (corticosteroid) to reduce inflammation and relieve pain. 
- If the patient continues to experience pain after the injection, will consider starting pain medication. 
- Will discuss surgery as a last resort if the patient's pain persists despite conservative treatment. 
2. Smoking cessation 
Assessment: The patient has a history of smoking. 
Plan: 
- Will provide counseling and resources for smoking cessation.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chronic lumbar back pain due to herniated disk at L4-L5 level with radiculopathy 
Assessment: The patient presented with chronic lumbar back pain, which started after a basketball injury 2 months ago. He described the pain as sharp and throbbing, and it radiates down his left leg. He also reported numbness in his toes. Physical exam revealed midline tenderness on the L4-L5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness when bending forward. Supine straight leg test was positive. Neurological exam showed decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome, patella, and Achilles reflexes were symmetrical. MRI showed disk desiccation, disk bulge with parasagittal disk herniation resulting in moderate right for neural foraminal stenosis. 
Plan: 
- Will perform spinal injection with a strong anti-inflammatory medication (corticosteroid) to reduce inflammation and relieve pain. 
- If the patient continues to experience pain after the injection, will consider starting pain medication. 
- If the patient still experiences pain after trying pain medication, will discuss surgery as a possible option.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Heart Failure Exacerbation
Assessment: The patient presented with shortness of breath, which resolved spontaneously within a few hours. He also has a history of heart failure and is currently compliant with his medications. His blood pressure is elevated today, suggesting possible decompensation of his CHF. Physical exam revealed mild lower extremity edema, crackles on lung exam, and supple neck. ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Echo showed normal LVEF. Differential diagnosis includes acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism, or PE. However, given his negative troponin and unchanged EKG, ACS is less likely. CXR is not suggestive of PE.
Plan:
- Will start Lasix 80mg QD.
- Will start Carvedilol 25mg BID.
- Adjust medications if needed based on response.
2. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is elevated today. He has a history of HTN.
Plan:
- Continue Lisinopril 40mg Qday.
3. History of Skin Cancer
Assessment: The patient had a basal cell carcinoma removed 5 months ago. He is currently without symptoms.
Plan:
- Follow up with dermatologist as scheduled.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure (CHF)
Assessment: The patient has a history of CHF, and his recent symptoms of shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and dizziness suggest an acute exacerbation of his CHF. His elevated blood pressure and trace lower extremity edema also support this diagnosis.
Plan:
- Will start the patient on an additional dose of Lasix 80 mg Qday.
- Will start the patient on Carvedilol 25 mg BID.
- Will monitor his response to these medications and make further adjustments as needed.
2. Skin cancer removal
Assessment: The patient had a skin cancer removed about 5 months ago, and he reports that everything has been fine since then.
Plan:
- Continue to monitor the patient's skin for signs of recurrence or complications.
3. Cataract surgery
Assessment: The patient had a cataract surgery about 3 months ago, and he reports that everything has been fine since then.
Plan:
- Continue to monitor the patient's visual acuity and ocular health.
4. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated today.
Plan:
- Will continue the patient's current antihypertensive regimen.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week for further evaluation and management.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Shortness of breath due to heart failure exacerbation
Assessment: The patient has a history of heart failure, and his recent symptoms of shortness of breath suggest an exacerbation of his condition. He also admits to consuming salty foods, which can cause retention of fluids and worsen his heart failure. His ECG and echocardiogram results are stable.
Plan:
- Will increase Lasix to 80 mg Qday.
- Will start Carvedilol 25 mg BID.
- Recommend strict adherence to heart healthy diet.
2. Skin cancer removal
Assessment: The patient had a skin cancer removed about 5 months ago, and the pathology report showed that it was completely excised. There were no signs of recurrence during today's examination.
Plan:
- No further intervention needed.
3. Cataract surgery
Assessment: The patient had a cataract surgery about 3 months ago, and the postoperative course was uneventful. There were no signs of complications or recurrence during today's examination.
Plan:
- No further intervention needed.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Congestive Heart Failure (LV EF 45%)
Assessment: Patient presented for her annual exam. She had a low-ischemic pumping function of the heart at about 45% and mitral regurgitation. She was retaining a little bit of fluid.
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 40mg Qday. 
- Start Lasix 20mg Qday. 
- Repeat ECHOCARDIOGRAM. 

2. Depression 
Assessment: Patient reported feeling well with therapy. No suicidal ideation or homicidal ideation. 
Plan: 
- Continue therapy. 

3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is elevated. Patient reports forgetting to take her blood pressure medication. Stress increases blood pressure. 
Plan: 
- Increase Lisinopril to 40mg Qday. 
- Instruct patient to record blood pressure daily and send to the doctor. 
- Schedule mammography. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up.

- Follow up in 1 month.

Assessment: The patient presents with new onset chest pain, likely due to severe hypertension. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain EKG and echocardiogram to evaluate for underlying cardiac cause of chest pain. 
- Will start carvedilol 25 mg BID for hypertension and coronary disease prevention. 
- Will refer to cardiology for further evaluation and management of possible CAD. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient has high blood pressure, with SBP around 180. 
Plan: 
- Will adjust current antihypertensive regimen by adding carvedilol 25 mg BID. 
- Will monitor blood pressure closely and adjust medication as needed. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up of blood pressure control and cardiac status.

- Return to clinic in two weeks for reassessment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Asthma exacerbation
Assessment: The patient presents with acute shortness of breath following strenuous exercise, suggestive of asthma exacerbation. He also has a history of allergies. Physical exam reveals expiratory wheeze bilaterally and trace lower extremity edema. Chest X-ray is normal. Pulmonary function tests are normal.
Plan:
- Prescribing albuterol inhaler, two puffs every four hours as needed for wheezing or shortness of breath.
- Ordering pulmonary referral.

2. Reflux 
Assessment: Patient reports managing his reflux well. No current issues.
Plan:
- Continue protonix.

3. Migraines
Assessment: Patient reports that his migraines are under control.
Plan:
- Continue Imitrex as needed.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks. If he experiences shortness of breath again, he should call the doctor right away.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE 
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Difficulty urinating. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant male who presents today for evaluation of difficulty urinating. He reports that over the last six months, his urination has become less forceful and he often needs to strain to void. He denies burning during urination, frequency, or nocturia. He also denies history of urinary retention or need for catheterization. The patient is a big college football fan and is excited that Georgia beat Alabama in the national championship. He is originally from Georgia, not Alabama. He is currently taking metformin for diabetes and follows a healthy diet. He has a history of coronary artery disease and takes lipitor, aspirin, and metoprolol. He sees Dr. Moore, his cardiologist, every few years. His last visit with Dr. Moore was in November 2022. The patient denies chest pain or shortness of breath. He walks around and exercises regularly.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE 
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Difficulty urinating. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of difficulty urinating. He reports that over the last six months, he has noticed that his urine stream is weak and he often feels like he is not completely emptying his bladder. He denies any burning during urination and states that he has been experiencing this issue for approximately six months. The patient also reports that he gets up about three or four times per night to use the bathroom due to this issue. Additionally, he notes that he has had diarrhea recently. The patient denies any history of urinary retention or any other issues related to his bowel movements. He also denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. He is currently taking metformin for diabetes control and follows a healthy diet.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Difficulty urinating
Assessment: Patient reports difficulty urinating, stream is weak, and he feels like he's not emptying his bladder fully. He also experiences nocturia and gets up multiple times at night to use the bathroom. Physical exam reveals an enlarged prostate. 
Plan: 
- Order routine labs (PSA, CBC, BMP) to rule out prostate cancer. 
- Start Flomax 0.4mg QHS. 
- Refer to Urology for further evaluation. 
2. Coronary artery disease
Assessment: Patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is currently asymptotic. Physical exam shows a mildly elevated JVP and a grade III/VI systolic ejection murmur at the left base. 
Plan: 
- Order ECHO to evaluate for changes in the heart since his previous study in ___. 
- Continue Lipitor 40mg Qday, Aspirin 81mg Qday, and Metoprolol Succinate 50mg Qday. 
3. Diabetes type II
Assessment: Patient has type II diabetes and is taking metformin 1000mg BID. His HbA1C is unknown. 
Plan: 
- Check HbA1C. 
- Continue Metformin 1000mg BID. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Call the office if you have any concerns. 
- Follow up in 3-4 weeks.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Difficulty urinating 
Assessment: Patient reports difficulty urinating, weak urinary stream, and incomplete voiding. He denies burning during urination and has no history of urinary retention. Physical exam reveals an enlarged prostate. 
Plan: 
- Order routine labs (PSA, CBC, chemistry) and urinalysis and urine culture. 
- Start Flomax 0.4mg QHS. 
- Refer to Urology for further evaluation and management. 
2. Coronary artery disease 
Assessment: Patient has a history of coronary artery disease with a recent stent placement in his right coronary artery. Cardiac murmur heard on physical exam. 
Plan: 
- Order ECHO to evaluate for changes in the heart since the last study. 
- Continue Lipitor 40mg Qday, Aspirin 81mg Qday, and Metoprolol XL 50mg Qday. 
- Order lipid panel. 
3. Diabetes mellitus type 2 
Assessment: Patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2. His sugar control appears to be adequate. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 1000mg BID. 
- Order Hemoglobin A1C to assess for need for medication adjustment. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Call the office if concerned. 
- Follow up in 3-4 weeks.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Difficulty urinating 
Assessment: Patient reports difficulty urinating, weak urinary stream, and incomplete voiding. He denies burning during urination. Physical exam reveals enlarged prostate. 
Plan: 
- Order PSA and urinalysis and urine culture. 
- Start Flomax 0.4 mg QHS.

- Continue Metformin 1000 mg BID. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Call or message the provider if concerned. 
- Follow up in 3-4 weeks.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a past medical history of depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension who presents for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports that the holiday season has been stressful, causing anxiety and pressure. He also states that he has been struggling with his diabetes management during the holidays. His vitals today are stable, including blood pressure and pulse. Physical exam reveals carotid bruits on the neck exam and a mildly increased LV ejection murmur on the heart exam. Examination of the lungs shows normal lung sounds. There is 1+ non-pitting edema bilaterally in the lower extremities. EKG showed no evidence of acute cardiac disease. Diabetic labs revealed an elevated HbA1C at 8%.

Musculoskeletal: Normal range of motion in the shoulders and elbows. Normal strength in the upper and lower extremities.
Abdominal: Soft, nontender abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal.
Extremities: Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema.

LABS
Haemoglobin A1C: Elevated (8).

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee posterolateral corner injury, likely posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) strain.
Assessment: The patient presents with right knee pain, swelling, and limited range of motion. She reports a history of PCL injury in her right knee when she was 14 years old. On examination, there is mild swelling and bruising on the right knee. There is tenderness to palpation on the right knee, particularly on the inner aspect. The patellar grind test is positive. The patient is able to bend her knee, but she walks with a limp. X-rays show early degenerative changes in the knee joint.
Plan: 
- Continue bracing the right knee. 
- Recommend physical therapy 3 times per week. 
- Prescribe meloxicam 15mg Qday and ibuprofen 800mg BID PRN for pain relief. 
2. Left knee instability due to previous surgery. 
Assessment: The patient has a history of left knee surgery. On examination, there is no evidence of fracture or acute injury. However, there is some swelling and bruising on the left knee. The patient reports occasional clicking and locking of the left knee.
Plan: 
- Monitor the left knee closely. 
- Consider referral to orthopedics for further evaluation and management.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee sprain, likely posterior cruciate ligament tear 
Assessment: Patient presents with right knee pain, limited range of motion, and swelling. She reports a history of surgery on her right knee as a child and has been skiing regularly. Exam reveals pain with palpation of the right knee, particularly on the medial side, and limitation of movement. X-ray shows early degenerative changes. 
Plan: 
- Continue to brace the right knee. 
- Recommend physical therapy 3x per week to improve strength and mobility. 
- Prescribe meloxicam 15mg Qday and ibuprofen 800mg BID PRN for left knee pain. 
2. Left knee pain 
Assessment: Patient reports left knee pain, which she attributes to instability. However, exam and x-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis. 
Plan: 
- Monitor symptoms and consider additional testing if necessary. 
- Consider referral to orthopedics if symptoms persist or worsen.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right posterolateral knee strain 
Assessment: The patient presents with right posterolateral knee pain, limited range of motion, and positive patellar tap test. X-ray shows early degenerative changes. Physical exam reveals pain with dorsiflexion but not with plantarflexion. 
Plan: 
- Continue bracing the right knee. 
- Recommend physical therapy 3 times a week. 
- Prescribe Meloxicam 15mg Qday and Ibuprofen 800mg BID PRN for left knee pain. 
2. Left knee pain 
Assessment: The patient reports left knee pain, which may be related to the right knee injury. However, physical exam and x-ray findings suggest a different etiology. 
Plan: 
- Monitor the left knee pain closely. If it persists or worsens, consider obtaining an MRI. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks for follow up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Shortness of breath, likely due to acute heart failure exacerbation 
Assessment: Patient presented with shortness of breath, which is likely due to acute heart failure exacerbation given his history of CAD s/p PCI and EF of 35%. He reports worsening shortness of breath over the past week and is currently taking Lasix 40mg Qday. His BNP is elevated and he has bibasilar rales on exam. 
Plan: 
- Increase Lasix from 40mg Qday to 80mg Qday. 
- Obtain Chest X-Ray to rule out other causes of shortness of breath. 
2. Coronary Artery Disease 
Assessment: Patient has a history of CAD s/p PCI and is currently asymptomatic. Echo showed EF of 35% and mild regional wall motion abnormalities consistent with prior infarction. 
Plan: 
- Order echo to evaluate cardiac function. 
3. Stage III Chronic Kidney Disease 
Assessment: Patient has stage III CKD with baseline Cr 1.5-1.7. He takes Lasix 40mg Qday. 
Plan: 
- Recommend avoidance of NSAIDs and Motrin. 
- Monitor renal function closely. 
- Consider starting ACEi or ARB if tolerated. 
4. Left Foot Pain 
Assessment: Patient reported left foot pain for 4-5 days, which resolved spontaneously. The pain was localized to the forefoot. It is possible that he has gout. 
Plan: 
- Order Uric Acid level to confirm diagnosis of gout. 
- If confirmed, consider treatment with Allopurinol. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for repeat evaluation of shortness of breath and CKD.
Note_2:

1. Shortness of breath 
Assessment: Acute heart failure exacerbation. 
Plan:

- Obtain chest X-ray.

Assessment: Patient is doing well, except for heart failure exacerbation. 
Plan: 
- Order echo cardiogram to check the heart murmur. 
3. Stage III chronic kidney disease 
Assessment: No evidence of renal injury. 
Plan: 
- Avoid NSAIDs. 
- Monitor creatinine. 
4. Possible gout flare 
Assessment: Unclear. 
Plan: 
- Order uric acid level. 
5. Dietary counseling 
Assessment: The patient needs dietary counseling due to his kidney disease. 
Plan:

Note_3:

1. Shortness of breath 
Assessment: Acute heart failure exacerbation, likely due to dietary indiscretion. 
Plan: 
- Increase Lasix from 40 mg Qday to 80 mg Qday. 
- Obtain CXR to rule out PNA. 
- Call Dr. ___ in 2 days to report weight change. 
- If weight increases, may need IV diuresis. 
2. Coronary artery disease 
Assessment: Stable, except for acute heart failure exacerbation. 
Plan: 
- Order ECHO to evaluate heart murmur. 
3. Stage III chronic kidney disease 
Assessment: Chronic kidney disease, stable. 
Plan: 
- Avoid NSAIDs. 
- Try Tylenol for pain. 
- Order complete metabolic panel to monitor renal function. 
4. Possible gout flare 
Assessment: Gout flare, unlikely given lack of joint redness, warmth, or swelling. However, uric acid level is elevated. 
Plan: 
- Order Uric acid level. 
- Consider colchicine or febuxostat if uric acid level is elevated.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Acute Lumbar Disk Herniation 
Assessment: The patient presents with left lower back pain, radiation to the left hip, and numbness in the right big toe, consistent with acute lumbar disk herniation. He denies fevers, chills, or urinary or bowel incontinence. Physical exam reveals decreased flexion and extension of the lower back, positive straight leg raise, and spasm of the paraspinal muscles of the lumbar spine. X-ray of the lumbar spine shows no acute bony abnormality. MRI will be ordered to further evaluate the extent of the herniation. 
Plan: 
- Will order a lumbar spine MRI to further evaluate the extent of the herniation. 
- Continue physical therapy. 
- Prescribed meloxicam 15mg once daily. 
- Discussed possible treatment options such as epidural steroid injection to reduce inflammation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up in 2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Anemia
Assessment: Hemoglobin level of 8.2. Normal range is 13-17.
Plan:
- Order CBC with differential.
- Schedule for endoscopy and colonoscopy.
- Will obtain anemia labs (iron studies, B12, folate) to determine etiology.

2. CopD
Assessment: No wheezing on exam. Patient reports being smoke free for several years.
Plan:
- Continue tobacco cessation counseling.
- Refer to pulmonary specialist if symptoms worsen.

3. Congestive Heart Failure
Assessment: Patient denying any swelling in her legs. She is compliant with diet and medications.
Plan:
- Continue toprol XL 50mg Qday, Lisinopril 20mg Qday, Lasix 20mg Qday.
- Monitor weight and fluid status.
- Consider adding spironolactone if weight continues to rise despite current treatment.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week or sooner if symptoms worsen.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Anemia 
Assessment: Hemoglobin level is 8.2, indicating anemia. Differential diagnosis includes iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 deficiency anemia, thalassemia, sickle cell disease, and chronic kidney disease. 
Plan: 
- Order anemia labs (iron studies, folate, vitamin B12) and send to lab. 
- Schedule patient for endoscopy and colonoscopy to rule out internal bleeding. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- I will call the patient to discuss the results of the anemia labs and schedule the procedures.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Anemia 
Assessment: Hemoglobin level is 8.2, which is below normal range. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain anemia labs to determine the cause of anemia. 
- Schedule endoscopy and colonoscopy to rule out internal bleeding. 
2. CopD 
Assessment: Patient reports being smoke free for several years. She denies any recent change in her breathing. 
Plan: 
- Continue to monitor breathing and provide education on COPD management. 
3. Congestive Heart Failure 
Assessment: Patient's vital signs are stable. Her heart sounds good on exam. She has mild systolic ejection murmur. 
Plan: 
- Continue Toprol XL 25mg Qday and Lisinopril 20mg Qday. 
- Continue Lasix 20mg Qday. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right shoulder acute acromioclavicular joint fracture 
Assessment: The patient presents today with complaints of right shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and decreased strength. Physical exam reveals pain to palpation of the posterior shoulder at the acromioclavicular joint, decreased abduction and adduction to about 90 degrees, pain with supination and pronation of the right arm, and a palpable radial artery pulse. X-ray shows an acute acromioclavicular joint fracture. 
Plan: 
- Sling for comfort. 
- Meloxicam 15mg Qday for pain. 
- Cat scan of right shoulder to evaluate the joint. 
- Referral to physical therapy for strengthening exercises. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for reevaluation.
Note_2:

Plan:

- Meloxicam 15mg Qday.
- Cat scan of the right shoulder.
- Physical therapy for strengthening exercises.

Assessment: The patient reports a slight headache.
Plan:
- Recommend over-the-counter pain medication if needed.
3. Neck pain
Assessment: The patient denies neck pain.
Plan:
- Continue to monitor for any changes in neck pain.
4. History of appendicitis
Assessment: The patient has a history of appendicitis and underwent an appendectomy.
Plan:
- No further intervention required.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Acute acromioclavicular joint fracture
Assessment: Patient presented with right shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and positive physical exam findings consistent with acute acromioclavicular joint fracture. X-ray confirmed the diagnosis.
Plan:
- Will place patient in a sling.
- Prescribed meloxicam 15mg Qday.
- Ordered CT scan of the right shoulder to further evaluate the joint.
- Referred to physical therapy to strengthen the shoulder in hopes of avoiding surgery in the future.
2. Headache
Assessment: Patient reported a slight headache after the injury. No fever or chills.
Plan:
- Recommend over-the-counter pain medication if needed.
3. History of appendicitis and appendectomy
Assessment: Patient reported history of appendicitis and appendectomy approximately 3-4 years ago.
Plan:
- Continue to monitor for recurrence of symptoms.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Uncontrolled Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient presents with persistent elevated blood pressure despite multiple medication adjustments. Physical exam reveals no jugular venous distention, no carotid bruits, and no heart murmurs. Renal artery ultrasound, 24-hour urine, morning aldosterone levels, and rein levels were ordered. The patient was instructed to decrease his alcohol intake and sodium intake, and to stop taking NSAIDs. He was prescribed Cardura 4mg Qday. 
Plan: 
- Follow-up in 3 weeks to review BP readings. 
- Continue current antihypertensive medications until further instructions from PCP. 
- Refer to nutritionist for education on low sodium diet. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Take Cardura 4mg Qday. 
- Record BP readings at home and bring them to follow-up appointment. 
- Decrease alcohol intake to 1x/week. 
- Stop taking NSAIDs.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Uncontrolled Hypertension
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension, currently being treated by her PCP. She reports that her blood pressure has been consistently elevated despite multiple medication changes. She also reports a family history of hypertension and kidney disease. Physical exam reveals a blood pressure of 169/74, heart rate of 88, and O2 saturation of 98%. There is no jugular venous distension, carotid bruit, or lung crackles.
Plan:
- Order renal artery ultrasound, morning aldosterone levels, reining levels, and 24-hour urine.
- Refer to nutritionist for salt reduction and dietary counseling.
- Stop taking NSAIDs (Advil, Motrin).
- Start Cardura 4mg Qday.
- Instruct patient to record BP measurements at home and bring them to follow-up appointment.
- Discussed with PCP regarding treatment plan.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 3 weeks for follow-up and to review results of lab tests.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Uncontrolled Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is elevated despite multiple medication changes. She has a family history of hypertension and kidney disease, which increases her risk of developing complications from hypertension. Physical examination reveals no jugular venous distention, carotid bruit, or pulmonary crackles. Renal artery ultrasound, morning aldosterone levels, reining levels, and a 24-hour urine were ordered to rule out any specific causes of hypertension. The patient was counseled to reduce her alcohol intake and salt intake. Cardura 4mg Qday was prescribed. The patient was referred to a nutritionist to discuss dietary modifications. 
Plan: 
- Continue current antihypertensive regimen (Norvasc 10mg Qday, Carvedilol 25mg BID). 
- Start Cardura 4mg Qday. 
- Refer to nutritionist for dietary modification. 
- Monitor blood pressure closely and adjust medications accordingly. 
- Follow up in 3 weeks to review progress.

The patient is a pleasant 17-year-old non-binary individual who presents for evaluation of newly diagnosed hypercholesterolemia. The patient reports being concerned about their elevated cholesterol, as it was discovered during their annual checkup. They deny any personal or family history of hypercholesterolemia, anemia, or other cardiovascular problems. They report being relatively active throughout the week and enjoying outdoor activities such as biking. Their diet is primarily composed of fresh, whole foods, although they admit to having a sweet tooth. They deny any smoking exposure at home or among their social contacts. They also report a positive family history of heart disease, specifically a cousin who died suddenly from a heart attack at the age of 45.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Hypercholesterolemia
Assessment: The patient has a family history of hypercholesterolemia, elevated LDL (20), and a positive CMPL test. There is no history of heart disease or sudden death in their family. Differential diagnosis includes familial hypercholesterolemia vs. secondary causes such as hypothyroidism or liver problems.
Plan:
- Order a full cholesterol panel, TSH, lipid panel, AST, ALT, Alk Phos, Total Bilirubin, Direct Bilirubin, GGT, LDH, Alanine Transaminase, Aspartate Transaminase, Alanine Aminotransferase, and Lipid Panel.
- Genetic testing to determine whether the problem is familial or secondary cause.
- Follow up in 3-6 months after meeting with a nutritionist and implementing dietary changes.
- Encourage a healthy diet low in saturated fats and sugars.
- Continue regular exercise, including biking.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

Assessment: Elevated LDL (20) and total cholesterol (185). No known family history of hypercholesterolemia, but grandparent reported cousin died of heart attack at age 44. Patient has normal BMI, exercises regularly, and denies smoking.
Plan:
- Order full cholesterol panel, glucose, CMP, TSH, liver panels, and genetic testing.
- Follow up in 3-6 months after meeting with nutritionist and implementing dietary changes.
- Continue regular exercise and maintain a balanced diet low in saturated fats and sugars.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 3-6 months for repeat cholesterol test and discussion of results.
Note_3:

Plan: 
- Continue to provide support and resources for the patient's non-binary identity.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Abdominal pain.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 34-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient reports that her abdominal pain began approximately 10 days ago with mild discomfort in the right side of her abdomen, which has progressively worsened over the past few days. She rates the pain as a 4 or 5 out of 10, although it can reach 7 or 8 at its worst. The pain is worse with meals and tends to be more severe after breakfast. It is also associated with nausea and heartburn, but there is no vomiting or diarrhea. The patient denies any changes in appetite or fatigue.

The patient notes that she has a history of chronic migraines and uses Excedrin as needed for treatment. She also uses Sumatriptan for breakthrough migraine pain. She states that she checks her blood pressure twice or three times a week and finds it to be within the range of 120/70 mmHg. She takes Lisinopril 20 mg PO Qday and requires a refill of this medication. Additionally, she requests a refill of Sumatriptan.

She rates the pain as a 4 or 5 out of 10, although it can increase to a 7 or 8. The pain is worse with meals, and she experiences some nausea and heartburn associated with the pain. It is also tender to palpation and tends to move to the left side of her abdomen. She denies any urinary symptoms such as dysuria, hematuria, or frequency. She also denies any changes in bowel movements. She reports that her appetite is slightly decreased due to nausea. She takes Excedrin Migraine as needed for migraines, and Sumatriptan as needed for breakthrough migraine pain. Her blood pressure is currently well controlled on Lisinopril 20mg Qday.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Abdominal Pain
Assessment: The patient presents with acute abdominal pain, right upper quadrant tenderness, and equivocal Murphy's sign. Differential diagnosis includes gallstones, infection, or pancreatitis.
Plan:
- Order CBC, chemistry panel, UA, pregnancy test, and RUQUS.
- Keep patient NPO until further evaluation.
- If results suggestive of gallstone or infection, may refer to surgery.
2. Migraine Headache
Assessment: Patient has a history of chronic migraines, currently using Excedrin as needed and Sumatriptan as needed for breakthrough migraine pain.
Plan:
- Continue Excedrin as needed.
- Continue Sumatriptan as needed.
- Encourage patient to avoid alcohol and caffeine binges and try to get enough sleep.
3. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure is currently under adequate control.
Plan:
- Continue Lisinopril 20mg Qday.
- Write refill prescription for Lisinopril.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

- Keep the patient NPO until further evaluation.

- Encourage the patient to avoid alcohol binges and caffeine binges, and to get enough sleep. 
3. Hypertension

- Continue Lisinopril 20mg Qday. 
- Write a refill prescription for Lisinopril.

- Follow up in 4 weeks or sooner if necessary.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Abdominal pain 
Assessment: The patient presents with acute abdominal pain, right upper quadrant tenderness, and positive Murphy's sign. She denies fever, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Differential diagnosis includes gallstone pancreatitis, appendicitis, or infection. 
Plan: 
- Order CBC, chemistry, lipid panel, LFTs, and pregnancy test. 
- Order right upper quadrant ultrasound. 
- Keep the patient NPO until further evaluation. 
2. Migraine headache 
Assessment: The patient has a history of chronic migraines and occasional bouts of migraines without recent episodes. 
Plan: 
- Continue Excedrin as needed for treatment. 
- Continue Sumatriptan as needed for breakthrough migraine pain. 
- Encourage the patient to avoid alcohol binges and caffeine binges and try to get enough sleep. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is currently under adequate control. 
Plan: 
- Continue Lisinopril 20mg Qday. 
- Write refill prescription for Lisinopril. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Twitching of the right eye.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 3-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of a new right eye twitch. The twitch began approximately 2 weeks ago, and the patient describes it as a face twitch that she feels occasionally. She denies pain associated with the twitch, but her father notes that he appears nervous when it happens. The twitch is intermittent, occurring several times per hour on some days and not at all on others. The patient has a history of soccer and enjoys spending time with her father.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
New right eye twitch.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 3-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of a new right eye twitch. The patient's father accompanies her to the appointment. The patient reports that she has been experiencing the eye twitch for approximately 2 weeks. She denies any associated pain, fever, chills, cough, headache, or difficulty sleeping. She states that the twitch is intermittent and occurs several times per hour. It usually starts on the right side of her face and spreads to the left side. She denies any history of seizures or Tourette's syndrome. She reports that the twitch does not affect her school performance or activities.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
New right eye twitch.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 3-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of a new right eye twitch. The patient's father accompanies her to the appointment. The patient denies any recent changes in vision, hearing, or balance. She denies any associated pain or weakness. She notes that the twitch is intermittent and occurs several times per hour. It usually starts on the right side of her face and spreads to the left side. She feels an urge to move her face when the twitch occurs. She denies any previous episodes of seizures or Tourette's syndrome. Her father states that the twitch began approximately 2 weeks ago and has been occurring daily since then. He notes that the twitch is always on the right side of her face and lasts for several seconds before stopping. He also notes that his daughter has been experiencing frequent blinking following the twitch.

Assessment: The patient has a tick eye twitch, which is very common in children and usually resolves on its own. The patient's examination is reassuring.
Plan:
- Will monitor the patient closely.
- Will advise the patient's parents to avoid drawing attention to the tick, as this can exacerbate the condition.
2. No further workup needed at this time.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Tick eye twitch
Assessment: The patient has a tick eye twitch, which is a common condition in children. It is likely benign and transient, and it does not appear to be impacting her school or activities.
Plan:
- No treatment is recommended at this time. If the twitch worsens or becomes bothersome, further evaluation and treatment can be considered.
2. Family history of seizures or Tourette's syndrome
Assessment: There is no known family history of seizures or Tourette's syndrome.
Plan:
- No action is required at this time.

- Return to clinic if the twitch worsens or becomes bothersome.

[doctor] michelle king , date of birth 01/05/1986 , mrnq27631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies .
[doctor] hello , are you mrs. king ?
[patient] i am .
[doctor] i'm dr. phillips . very nice to meet you .
[patient] you as well .
[doctor] how can i help you today ?
[patient] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i've just got really bad acid reflux .
[doctor] okay . can you tell me more about it ?
[patient] yeah . though i mean i ... right now , i take 40 milligrams of omeprazole twice a day . some days , it is fine , but others are just really bad .
[doctor] what do you feel ?
[patient] it feels like burning .
[doctor] in your chest ?
[patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat .
[doctor] in your throat and chest . all right . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ?
[patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years .
[doctor] okay . and how long have you been on the omeprazole ?
[patient] on the way , it is now i think about a year .
[doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ?
[patient] i mean , i can tell it's helped because some days , i'll be fine , and then some days , i eat something and it feels terrible .
[doctor] are there any things that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint , like food choices or stress ?
[patient] sure . probably stress and food choices sometimes .
[doctor] okay . what things bother you ?
[patient] spicy foods , um , so i try not to eat them too often , but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it .
[doctor] we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that , even sodas . um , even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato-based products or citrus products ?
[patient] yeah , sometimes , but i still eat them .
[doctor] okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing , though . how's your weight been ? pretty stable ?
[patient] i'd say pretty stable , although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past two months . i have been under a lot of work stress .
[doctor] what do you do for work ?
[patient] i'm a paralegal .
[doctor] okay . and any family history of gi issues ?
[patient] um , my grandmother had esophageal cancer .
[doctor] on your mom or dad's side ?
[patient] mom's side . and my mom had some issues like acid reflux , and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach .
[doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ?
[patient] i think maybe when i was younger .
[doctor] but not in the last 10 years ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ?
[patient] um , at one point i was on omeprazole and ranititine -dine . it did help . but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken .
[doctor] okay . have a seat here , and let me listen to your heart and lungs , and then we can talk about a plan for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so normal physical exam per my new patient template , except for well-healed abdominal surgical scars noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ?
[patient] i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around one month old .
[doctor] hm , gotcha . okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several-year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole , 40 milligrams twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ?
[patient] yes .
[doctor] and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated bev- beverages , citrus , and tomato-based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd , even though you're taking the ppi .
[patient] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods .
[doctor] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms .
[patient] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me .
[doctor] so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally , we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium .
[patient] that's fine with me . i'm definitely open to trying whatever .
[doctor] perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 milligrams twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i'll also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd , or upper endoscopy , to look for potential causes of the gerd . we'd sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth , down your throat , through your stomach , and end in the small intestines . we'd look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything .
[patient] okay . can i schedule that today ?
[doctor] yeah . you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary , stress , and medication changes . how does all of that sound ?
[patient] that sounds good .
[doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the checkout desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment .
[doctor] please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms pers- persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph-impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) 
Assessment: Patient presents with 10+ year history of GERD, poorly controlled with current PPI therapy. She reports frequent triggers including spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, and tomato-based products. She has a positive family history of GI issues, specifically esophageal cancer in her maternal grandmother. She denied any unintentional weight loss or dysphagia. Differential diagnosis includes functional gastrointestinal disorder (FGID). 
Plan: 
- Will start Nexium 40mg BID. 
- Schedule EGD and follow-up with Dr. ___ in 2 weeks. If EGD is normal and symptoms persist, will consider trial of Protonix and obtain a pH-impedance study. 
2. Stress and anxiety 
Assessment: Patient reports significant stress and anxiety related to her job as a paralegal. She agrees to explore coping strategies and relaxation techniques to manage her stress and anxiety. 
Plan: 
- Referral to mental health professional if desired. 
- Provide education on stress management techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Call the office if any questions or concerns arise before the EGD and follow-up appointment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Assessment: Patient presents with a several-year history of GERD, poorly controlled with omeprazole 40mg BID. She identifies trigger foods such as spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, and tomato-based foods, but has not cut these foods out of her diet completely. Stress is also a trigger for her symptoms.
Plan:
- Change diet to avoid trigger foods.
- Start Nexium 40mg Qday.
- Schedule EGD to evaluate for potential causes of GERD.
- Follow up in 1 week after EGD to discuss results and treatment options.

2. Anxiety and seasonal allergies
Assessment: Patient reports anxiety and seasonal allergies.
Plan:
- Continue current treatment regimen.
- Consider referral to mental health specialist for further management.

Follow-up instructions:
- Call the office if any questions or concerns arise before the EGD and follow-up appointment.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Assessment: Patient presents with persistent GERD despite treatment with omeprazole. She reports trigger foods such as spicy foods, carbonated beverages, citrus, and tomato-based products. She also reports stress and anxiety as triggers. Differential diagnosis includes functional GI disorder vs. PPI-resistant GERD.
Plan:
- Will start Nexium 40mg BID.
- Recommend dietary modifications, including avoiding trigger foods.
- Schedule EGD to evaluate for potential causes of GERD.
- If EGD is normal and symptoms persist, will consider trial of Protonix and obtain a pH impedance study.
2. Anxiety and stress
Assessment: Patient reports significant anxiety and stress.
Plan:
- Will provide counseling and support.
- Consider referral to mental health specialist if needed.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks after EGD to review results and discuss further management.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Elevated Blood Pressure
Assessment: The patient reports occasional hypertension, with SBPs > 180 mmHg. He denies lightheadedness, headache, chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Physical exam is benign. Differential diagnosis includes secondary causes such as renal artery stenosis, pheochromocytoma, primary aldosterone excess, Cushing's syndrome.
Plan:
- Increase lisinopril to 60 mg BID.
- Add HCTZ 25 mg Qday.
- Check blood pressure twice daily for 2 weeks.
- Follow-up in 2 weeks.
2. Hyperlipidemia
Assessment: The patient's LDL is unknown. His lipid profile will be sent.
Plan:
- Continue Atorvastatin 40 mg Qday.
3. Osteoarthritis
Assessment: The patient has mild OA without significant pain or limitation of motion.
Plan:
- Continue Tylenol PRN for pain.
- Encourage ambulation and exercise.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHRISTINE is a pleasant 63-year-old female who presents for her annual examination. She reports that she has been feeling well since her last visit. She denies any suicidal ideation or homicidal ideation. She reports that she has been taking her antihypertensive medication regularly. However, she notes that her blood pressure has been labile recently, ranging from hypertensive to hypotensive. She attributes this to stress and lack of time to maintain a healthy diet due to increased working hours. She denies any headache, swelling, or numbness/tingling in her extremities. Her carpal tunnel release surgery two years ago has been successful and she does not experience any tingling or numbness in her hands.
Note_2:

CHRISTINE is a pleasant 63-year-old female who presents for her annual physical examination. She reports a history of high blood pressure and depression. She denies any suicidal ideation or homicidal ideation. She states that her mood is currently stable and that she has been managing her depression well with medication and therapy. She reports having some headaches but attributes them to computer use. She denies any numbness or tingling in her hands or feet. Her carpal tunnel release surgery two years ago has been successful.

Her carpal tunnel release surgery two years ago has been successful, and she denies any numbness or tingling in her hands or feet.
