Dialogue:
[doctor] patrick allen . date of birth : 7/7/1977 . new patient visit . past medical history includes gerd , anxiety , depression . here for chronic abdominal pain . he had an abdominal ct on 1/23/2020 . impression is a normal ct of the ab- abdomen .
[doctor] hello , are you mr. allen ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] hi . my name is dr. edwards . nice to meet you .
[patient] nice to meet you .
[doctor] welcome to the gi specialty clinic .
[patient] thank you .
[doctor] did you have any problems finding us ?
[patient] no , i've been here with my sister once before .
[doctor] good . so how can i help you today ? uh , the referral i have is for abdominal pain and diarrhea .
[patient] right . so i've had ... i've been having this pain right here in my stomach , like right around here .
[doctor] so in the area of your mid abdomen , just below the belly button ?
[patient] correct . i've had the pain on and off for about two years . i finally went to the er and a ... a few months ago and they did a ct scan .
[doctor] i saw that .
[patient] yeah . they said they did n't really see anything on the scan .
[doctor] yes , i agree . it looked normal .
[patient] the problem is i'm either constipated or have explosive diarrhea .
[doctor] is the pain there all the time ?
[patient] it's a nagging feeling and it just depends . sometimes it bothers me , sometimes it does n't .
[doctor] has this been the case over the past two years as well ?
[patient] more recently in the past couple months , at least with the constipation and diarrhea .
[doctor] and before that , how are your bowel movements ?
[patient] they were normal .
[doctor] uh , okay . so any blood in your stool ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ?
[patient] probably more constipation .
[doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ?
[patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard .
[doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ?
[patient] about three to four times a week . it's like when i need to go to the bathroom , if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go .
[doctor] okay . and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ?
[patient] yeah , it gets a little better .
[doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay ? any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ?
[patient] none of that .
[doctor] okay . so tell me about the diarrhea , how often do you get it ?
[patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach . if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce , i'm probably gon na have diarrhea .
[doctor] okay . and it does n't happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ?
[patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over .
[doctor] and how's your weight been ? any fluctuation ?
[patient] nice and pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds .
[doctor] okay . and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ?
[patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even thought i've never been diagnosed with it .
[doctor] okay . and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ?
[patient] i've never had any surgery .
[doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all those are still intact ?
[patient] yup .
[doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ?
[patient] no . i thought that happen when you turn 50 .
[doctor] well , that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy , like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my steth- stethoscope . and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants .
[patient] what does that mean ? is everything okay ?
[doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] so now , i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen . let me know if you have any pain .
[patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side , near my belly button .
[doctor] okay . i do feel stool in your lower colon , which would coincide with constipation , but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ?
[patient] yes , i have a physical about four months ago and they ... i had blood drawn then .
[doctor] okay . and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ?
[patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes , but we would recheck them in about six months .
[doctor] and you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ?
[patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated .
[doctor] and do you take any medications , either prescription or over-the-counter ?
[patient] i take crestor and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasion- occasional pain .
[doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ?
[patient] hardly ever . maybe once a month .
[doctor] and do you consume alcohol ?
[patient] uh , yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays .
[doctor] okay . and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice .
[patient] what would cause that ?
[doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] lungs are clear , bilateral heart sounds are normal , no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted .
[patient] that's good .
[doctor] yes . the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly .
[patient] what's that ?
[doctor] increase stool burden means that there's a lot of stool sitting in your colon .
[patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ?
[doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged .
[patient] but you said mine was slightly enlarged ?
[doctor] correct .
[patient] so what does that mean ?
[doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged .
[patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ?
[doctor] no , i think you're constipated and have occasional bouts of diarrhea because of certain foods you eat . and we can get you started right away on a fiber supplement that should help with that .
[patient] so what about my liver ? why is it enlarged ?
[doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to liver , alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease .
[patient] so what do i need to do ?
[doctor] well , i think since it's been about four months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs .
[patient] okay . and then what ?
[doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too .
[patient] which medications ?
[doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ?
[patient] about 18 months .
[doctor] okay . well , crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives .
[patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ?
[doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol .
[patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon .
[doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that .
[patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ?
[doctor] hopefully , within the next two weeks . you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up .
[patient] okay . and then what happens ?
[doctor] when i get the results from the test , i will contact you . and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps .
[patient] and when should i see you again ?
[doctor] uh , let's schedule an appointment when you check out to return in four weeks . we'll discuss how you're doing with the fiber supplement and your constipation and review test results to determine if we need to do further testing on your liver .
[patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ?
[doctor] definitely refrain from drinking any alcohol , increase your water intake to at least 48 ounces a day in addition to taking the fiber supplement to help with your constipation . and be mindful of eating foods that you were sensitive to so you can avoid the bouts of diarrhea .
[patient] okay . and i'll talk to my primary care about my crestor .
[doctor] excellent . and do you have any other questions for me ?
[patient] i do n't think so .
[doctor] great . so remember when you check out the front desk , schedule follow-up appointment with me for four weeks and then go to the lab to get your blood work drawn .
[patient] okay . sounds good .
[doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound .
[patient] all right . thanks , dr. edwards .
[doctor] thank you , mr. allen .
label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the GI clinic for evaluation of abdominal pain. He reports that he has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain located in his mid-abdomen, specifically around the belly button, for approximately 2 years. The pain is described as a nagging sensation that varies in severity. It tends to be worse during episodes of constipation. He denies nausea, vomiting, bloating, or abdominal distension. He also denies a history of melena or hematochezia.

The patient reports that he has a history of constipation and diarrhea. He states that he typically has a bowel movement every 3 to 4 days and describes the stool as being hard. When he has a bowel movement, his abdominal pain improves. He also reports a history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) in his sister.

The patient denies a history of surgery on his abdomen, including appendectomy, cholecystectomy, or hernia repair. He denies a history of colonoscopy. He denies a history of alcohol or drug abuse. He denies a history of hepatitis B or C. He denies a history of viral exposure or immune deficiency. He denies a history of inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis).

Physical examination reveals bowel sounds in all four quadrants. There is a small amount of stool in the lower colon, consistent with constipation. The patient has a slightly enlarged liver, which is most likely due to steatosis.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the GI clinic for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient reports that he has had intermittent abdominal pain, mostly located in his midabdomen, for approximately 2 years. He describes the pain as a dull ache that is worse with constipation. The patient also reports episodes of explosive diarrhea. He denies any nausea, vomiting, heartburn, or indigestion. The patient states that he has been eating and drinking normally.  The patient reports that his sister has irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The patient denies any prior surgeries on his abdomen. He denies any colonoscopies. The patient takes Crestor and Olmesartan daily for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He occasionally takes Tylenol for pain relief. The patient denies any alcohol consumption.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the GI clinic for evaluation of abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea. He reports experiencing abdominal pain in his mid-abdomen, specifically around his belly button, for approximately 2 years. The pain is intermittent and worsens with constipation or diarrhea. He denies any nausea, vomiting, heartburn, or indigestion. He also denies any family history of GI issues. He reports a history of constipation and occasional diarrhea, which he attributes to specific foods. He takes Crestor and Olmesartan daily and Tylenol occasionally for pain. He consumes alcohol on occasion. He denies any history of heavy alcohol or drug use.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea 
Assessment: The patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea. He has a normal CT abdomen from ___. Differential diagnosis includes IBS, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), functional dyspepsia, or underlying malignancy. 
Plan: 
- Will order liver function tests, CBC, and CRP. 
- Recommend increasing water intake and starting fiber supplement. 
- Advise against alcohol consumption. 
- Refer to GI specialist. 
2. Elevated liver enzymes 
Assessment: The patient has elevated liver enzymes on his recent bloodwork. Possible etiologies include fatty liver disease, hepatitis, cirrhosis, or Wilson's disease. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain liver ultrasound. 
- Discuss alternative medications for high cholesterol. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is currently controlled. 
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 10mg Qday. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chronic abdominal pain 
Assessment: The patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, constipation, and occasional diarrhea. He has a history of GERD and anxiety. His physical exam is benign except for hepatomegaly. LFTs are pending. CT abdomen was negative. 
Plan: 
- Will order liver function tests (LFTs) and CBC. 
- Recommend increasing fluid intake to at least 48 ounces per day and starting a fiber supplement to help with constipation. 
- Encourage the patient to avoid alcohol and foods that trigger his symptoms.  

2. Elevated liver enzymes 
Assessment: The patient has elevated ALT and AST. 
Plan: 
- Obtain liver ultrasound. 
- Discuss alternative medications to crestor with PCP. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea
Assessment: The patient presents with a history of chronic abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea. He has a normal CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. His physical exam reveals bowel sounds in all four quadrants, suggesting active bowel function. However, he has a slightly enlarged liver, which could be due to various etiologies such as medication toxicity, alcohol abuse, fatty liver disease, hepatitis, cirrhosis, or Wilson's disease.
Plan:
- Will obtain laboratory tests including liver enzymes, CBC, chemistry panel, and LFTs.
- Will order a liver ultrasound.
- Will discuss alternative medications to Crestor.
- Will advise the patient to refrain from drinking alcohol, increase his water intake to at least 48 ounces a day, and take a fiber supplement to help with constipation.
- Will schedule a follow-up appointment in four weeks.

Follow-up instructions:
- If the patient experiences worsening symptoms or develops fevers, chills, or abdominal pain, he should seek immediate medical attention.

[patient] hey document i i do n't know i'm doing alright i guess
[doctor] just alright how's it
[patient] well
[doctor] how's it been since you've had your heart attack have you been have you been doing alright
[patient] no i've been seeing you for years since i had my last heart attack in two thousand eighteen but i've been doing pretty good i ca n't believe this happened again i mean i'm doing okay i guess i just feel tired every now and then and but overall i mean i guess i feel pretty well
[doctor] okay good were you able to enjoy the spring weather
[patient] yeah some i mean i'm hoping now that i've had my little procedure that i'll feel better and feel like getting back out and and maybe doing some walking there is some new trails here behind the rex center and maybe get out and walk those trails
[doctor] that will be fine i know you love walking the trails i know you like looking at the flowers because i think you you plant a lot of flowers as well do n't you especially around this time
[patient] yeah i do some gardening around the house
[doctor] yeah
[patient] and you know i really like photography too being able to go out and take nature pictures
[doctor] yeah
[patient] so i'm hoping to be able to go out and do that
[doctor] okay well we'll we'll do what we can here to get you out and going doing all those fun activities again now tell me have you had any chest pain or any shortness of breath
[patient] no not really no chest pain or shortness of breath i've been doing some short walks right around the house so like around the block
[doctor] okay
[patient] but i stay pretty close to the house i've been doing some light housekeeping and i do n't know i seem to be doing okay i think
[doctor] okay alright now tell me are you able to lay flat at night when you sleep or
[patient] well i mean i i never have truly laid flat on my back i've always slept with two pillows which is normal for me
[doctor] okay
[patient] so i mean i guess i really do n't have any troubles with my sleeping
[doctor] okay good how about are your legs swelling up

[patient] well
[doctor] alright so why do n't we go ahead and do a quick physical exam on you here i just want to take a look at you your vital signs look good i'm glad to see you're tolerating the medication well i'm gon na go ahead and feel your neck here i do n't appreciate any jugular venous distention and there are no carotid bruits on your heart exam there is a three out of six six systolic ejection murmur it's heard at the left base but that's pretty much the same as last year so we'll continue to monitor that okay let me listen to your lungs here real quick russell your lungs are clear so good good and your extremities i do n't see any swelling or edema on your right radial artery the cath site there is clean and it's dry and intact and i do n't see any hematoma so that's good and there is a palpable rra pulse so russell i did review the results of your ekg which showed normal sinus rhythm good r wave progression and evolutionary changes which are anticipated so let's go ahead and talk about my assessment plan for you for your first diagnosis of coronary artery disease we are gon na have you continue your your aspirin eighty one milligrams daily and brilinta ninety milligrams twice daily and we're gon na have you continue on that high dose statin that atorvastatin you might call it lipitor eighty milligrams daily and then also continue on that toprol fifty milligrams daily okay and i'm also going to refer you to cardiac rehab so for you to get some education about your heart and also give you the confidence to get back exercising regularly now i know patients love the cardiac rehab program i think you will do well does that sound good to you
[patient] that sounds good document
[doctor] alright so for your second diagnosis here the newly reduced left ventricular dysfunction and moderate mitral regurgitation i think your pumping function will improve in time you know they got you to the lab quickly so i think that heart muscle is just stunned and you're very compliant you're very good with your medications and following through with those so i think it will recover so that said i want you to go ahead and continue continue your lisinopril twenty milligrams a day i do n't think you need a diuretic at this time but i do want to add aldactone twelve . five milligrams daily and then you'll need to get labs next week okay and then we're gon na repeat another echocardiogram echocardiocardiogram in about two months
[patient] okay
[doctor] okay and then for your hypertension your third diagnosis of hypertension i want your to take your blood pressure just like you would you know every so often and then because your blood pressures actually seem fine at this time so we will continue to monitor that and i think you will tolerate the aldactone well as well
[patient] alright sounds good document
[doctor] okay well you take care and you have a good evening
[patient] yeah you too
[doctor] bye

CHIEF COMPLAINT
Hospital follow-up after anterior STEMI, NSTEMI, LAD and EF 30% and MR.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 45-year-old male who presents for hospital follow-up after an anterior STEMI now status post drug-eluting stent and LAD and newly reduced ejection fraction (EF) 35% and moderate mitral regurgitation. The patient reports feeling tired every now and then but otherwise feels pretty well. He has enjoyed the spring weather and hopes to go out and take nature pictures. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, leg swelling, or trouble sleeping. The patient takes his medications as prescribed and has good insurance. He is aware of the importance of changing his diet and watching his salt intake.
Note_2:

The patient is a 45-year-old male with past medical history significant for CAD status post prior RCA stent in 2018, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus who presents for hospital follow-up after an anterior STEMI now status post drug-eluting stent and LAD and newly reduced ejection fraction (35%) and moderate mitral regurgitation. The patient reports feeling tired every now and then and has been doing pretty well overall. He enjoys walking the trails behind the Rex Center and looking at the flowers. He also likes photography and hopes to go out and do that soon. The patient denies chest pain or shortness of breath. He takes his medications as prescribed and has been taking them since he got out of the hospital. He is aware of the importance of cutting back on salt and salty foods to help his heart function at its best.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

The patient reports feeling tired every now and then and having trouble enjoying the spring weather due to his recent heart attack. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath. He has been taking his medicines as prescribed and has been able to afford them. He has been taking salt precautions and changing his diet.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Anterior STEMI, CAD s/p DES x2, LV dysfunction, MR
Assessment: The patient has a history of multiple risk factors including HTN, DM, and HLD. He presented with chest pain, found to have NSTEMI and underwent PCI with DES x2. Echo showed EF 35% and moderate MR. 
Plan: 
- Continue Aspirin 81mg Qday, Brilinta 90mg BID, Atorvastatin 80mg Qday, Toprol XL 50mg Qday. 
- Refer to cardiac rehab. 
- Repeat echo in 2 months. 
2. Hypertension
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure is currently well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Monitor blood pressure closely. 
3. Diabetes Mellitus
Assessment: Patient's glucose control is adequate. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Coronary artery disease (CAD)
Assessment: The patient has a history of CAD, s/p RCA stent in ___, now s/p DES to LAD and EF 35%. He reports feeling fatigued and short of breath with exertion. Physical exam reveals no JVD, no carotid bruits, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base, and no hematoma at the cath site. EKG shows normal sinus rhythm and evolutionary changes.
Plan:
- Continue Aspirin 81mg Qday, Brilinta 90mg BID, Atorvastatin 80mg Qday, Toprol XL 50mg Qday.
- Refer to Cardiac Rehab.
2. Reduced left ventricular function (EF 35%) and moderate mitral regurgitation
Assessment: The patient has a newly reduced left ventricular function and moderate mitral regurgitation. His pumping function may improve over time. He is compliant with his medications and follows through with them.
Plan:
- Continue Lisinopril 20mg Qday.
- Add Aldactone 12.5mg Qday.
- Obtain labs next week.
- Repeat echo in 2 months.
3. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient's blood pressures are currently well controlled.
Plan:
- Monitor blood pressure regularly.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) 
Assessment: Patient has a history of CAD, s/p RCA stent in 2018, now status post DES to LAD and EF 35%. He reports feeling fatigued and having trouble with his sleep. Physical exam reveals no JVD, no carotid bruits, and a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base. EKG shows normal sinus rhythm, good R wave progression, and evolutionary changes. 
Plan: 
- Continue Aspirin 81mg Qday, Brilinta 90mg BID, Atorvastatin 80mg Qday, Toprol XL 50mg Qday. 
- Refer to Cardiac Rehab. 
2. Reduced Left Ventricular Function (EF 35%) and Moderate Mitral Regurgitation 
Assessment: Patient has recently developed reduced LV function and MR. His pumping function may improve over time. 
Plan: 
- Continue Lisinopril 20mg Qday. 
- Add Aldactone 12.5mg Qday. 
- Obtain labs next week. 
- Repeat echo in 2 months. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure is currently well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Monitor blood pressure regularly.

Dialogue:
[doctor] so anna good to see you today so reading here in your appointment notes you were you were diagnosed with kidney stones from your your pcp and you currently have one and so they they had you come in so can you tell me what happened how's all that going for you
[patient] sure i've been having some back pain on my right side it's been lasting for about a week now
[doctor] okay
[patient] and i also started to see some blood in my urine
[doctor] okay so on the right side so does that pain does it move anywhere or is it just kinda stay in that that one area
[patient] yeah it's moved down a little bit on to my right lower side a little bit
[doctor] side okay so how would you describe the pain is it constant or is does it come and go
[patient] it's pretty constant
[doctor] okay did you notice any pain when you're urinating i know i know you say you you saw you see blood but any pain with that
[patient] no no real pain when i'm when i'm peeing at all
[doctor] okay so have you taken anything i know have you tried like azo or any of that to
[patient] i took some ibuprofen that helped a little bit
[doctor] okay
[patient] but it still hurts even with ibuprofen
[doctor] alright have you noticed any nausea vomiting fever chills
[patient] i have n't thrown up but i felt a little bit nauseated
[doctor] little nauseated yeah that's we expected so have you do you have a family history of kidney stones i know some people when they have them like their parents have them stuff but
[patient] yeah my my dad had kidney stones i think he has passed a couple of them i'm not quite sure
[doctor] alright and have you had any in the past or is this your first one
[patient] this is my first time i've never had this before
[doctor] okay alright so we'll do we'll do an exam on you just to check you out so i guess you were in pain and stuff over the over the easter easter break there that
[patient] yeah yeah i had some pain over the weekend i saw my pediatrician this morning so they sent me over here they were concerned that i might have a kidney stone
[doctor] okay so i'm guessing you did n't get to go find the eggs on the easter egg hunt because of the you were in pain
[patient] not so much but i i got to participate a little bit i opened some eggs i just did n't go run around and find them
[doctor] okay well i i'm lucky enough my friends had an adult easter hag hunt for me and so i was able to find a couple eggs yesterday myself so i i'm glad you were able to get a few of them alright so let's do that that physical exam on you so your vitals look good you do n't have any fever your blood pressure heart rate is fine so when i press here on your belly does that hurt
[patient] a little bit yeah
[doctor] a little bit alright so on your exam of your abdomen there is mild pain and tenderness to palpation of the abdomen there's no rebound or guarding there is cva located near your flank tenderness on the right so that means that everything looks good but you do have what seems to be some inflammation of your kidney okay so we we were able to get a ct of your your side and it showed that you do have a stone measuring point five centimeters in size and it's located in the proximal right ureter and so that's that duck that passes from your kidney to your bladder alright i do n't see any evidence of hydronephrosis so that means that there's not obstructing ureter causing swelling in your kidney which is which is pretty good so let's talk a little bit about my assessment and plan so you do have that kidney stone on the right so what i'm recommending is i want you to push fluids just to help facilitate you passing that stone alright have you been taking in have you been drinking enough water do you think so far
[patient] probably not enough i drink some but
[doctor] okay yeah i i want you to to drink try drink as much as possible just to see if we can get you hydrated and pass the stone what i'm gon na do is i'm gon na prescribe you ibuprofen eight hundred milligrams you can take that as needed for pain i know you said you were in that much pain just in case it does start to move you're in pain i want you to take the ibuprofen i'm also gon na give you a strainer for you to strain your pee so we can see you wan na know when that that stone does pass gon na order a bmp and a urinalysis and a urine culture and based on what the urinalysis shows we can decide if i can decide if i need to put you on antibiotics if you do have an infection of some kind and i wan na see you back in about a week to two weeks and if you're still having symptoms we can discuss further treatment such as a lithotripsy and it's it's a mainly minimally invasive procedure where we use shock waves to try to break up that stone but otherwise do you have any other questions for me
[patient] no i do n't think so
[doctor] alright so we will see you back in a week or two and i'll have my nurse come in with that prescription and hopefully with all the treatment you'll be able to pass the stone okay alright
label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE 
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Right sided back pain, hematuria. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right sided back pain and hematuria. He reports his pain began approximately 1 week ago and is primarily localized to the right lower side. The pain is constant and does not radiate. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or fevers. He takes ibuprofen for pain relief. The patient also reports seeing blood in his urine. He has a positive family history of kidney stones, as his father has passed several. This is the patient's first kidney stone. The patient was seen by his pediatrician this morning, who referred him to the clinic due to concern for a kidney stone.
Note_2:

His pain is described as constant and is exacerbated by movement. He denies any associated nausea, vomiting, or fevers. He also denies any change in urinary frequency or urgency. He reports seeing blood in his urine for the past day. He denies any history of kidney stones in himself or his family members. He states that he has not taken any medications for his current condition.

This is his first episode of hematuria.

- Follow up in 3 months or sooner if symptoms worsen.

Plan:
- Will refer patient to Emergency Department for chest X-ray and CT scan.
- Will obtain blood tests, including CBC, electrolytes, liver function tests, and coagulation studies.

2. Diabetes mellitus type II:

Plan:
- Will repeat hemoglobin A1C today.
- Will increase metformin dosage from 500mg BID to 750mg BID.
3. Hypertension:
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure has been running somewhat low.
Plan:
- Hold Norvasc until further evaluation.
4. Asthma:
Assessment: The patient reports a history of asthma.
Plan:
- Continue Symbicort and Albuterol PRN.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 3 weeks to discuss diabetes management and medications.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chest Pain 
Assessment: Unlikely ACS given EKG with no ST changes, negative troponins x2, and no risk factors. Concerning for stable angina, however, patient denies typical anginal symptoms (CP, DOE). Differential diagnosis includes GERD, costochondritis, musculoskeletal chest pain.
Plan: 
- Will refer to cardiology for further evaluation and management. 
- Started Aspirin 81 mg PO Qday. 
- Prescribed Nitro SL PRN. If chest pain persists while ambulating, take 1 tablet and wait 5 min. If still persistent, repeat. If still persistent, go to ED immediately. 
- Continue current diabetes management. 
- Consider outpatient stress testing. 
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II 
Assessment: Hemoglobin A1C 7%. Patient reports being compliant with diet and exercise. However, she has recently experienced increased glucose levels due to decreased physical activity. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 500 mg BID. 
- Order HbA1c again in 2 weeks. 
- Refer to ophthalmologist for diabetic retinopathy screening. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure elevated on multiple occasions. No evidence of end organ damage. 
Plan: 
- Start Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg PO Qday. 
- Instruct patient to monitor blood pressure at home using a blood pressure cuff and log results in Epic MyChart. 
- Schedule follow-up visit in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Chest pain: Unstable angina, possible coronary artery disease.
Assessment: The patient presents with chest pain that occurs during physical activity and resolves with rest. She has a positive family history of heart disease and a history of diabetes and hypertension. Her ECG shows no evidence of acute ST segment changes or T wave inversion. She is referred to cardiology for further evaluation and management.
Plan:
- Start aspirin 81 mg Qday.
- Prescribe Nitro tablets (20mg) PRN chest pain. If the pain does not improve within 5 minutes, instruct her to seek immediate medical attention.
- Referral to cardiology.

2. Diabetes: type II diabetes.
Assessment: The patient has poorly controlled diabetes with A1C of 7%. She is followed by endocrine and ophthalmology for diabetic retinopathy.
Plan:
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID.
- Order Hemoglobin A1C today.
- Recommend continued diet control and exercise.
- Ophthalmology follow-up as scheduled.

3. Hypertension: Mild hypertension.
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension, although never on treatment. 
Plan:
- Start Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday.
- Instruct the patient to measure her blood pressure at home using a blood pressure cuff.
- Ask the patient to enter her blood pressure readings in Epic MyChart.
- Follow up with the patient in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment and adjust medications as needed.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chest pain 
Assessment: The patient presents with chest pain, likely due to stable angina given her history of diabetes and suspected hypertension. She has no known history of heart disease, but her family history suggests a risk. Her ECG is normal. 
Plan: 
- Will refer to cardiology for further evaluation and management. 
- Started aspirin 81 mg Qday. 
- Instructed patient to take aspirin if she experiences chest pain while walking, and to seek immediate medical attention if the pain does not improve within 5 minutes. 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: The patient has type 2 diabetes, controlled by diet and exercise. Her HbA1C is 7%. She has an appointment for an eye exam in 2 weeks. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500 mg BID. 
- Order hemoglobin A1C today. 
- Refer to ophthalmology for diabetic retinopathy screening. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension, although it is not well documented in her records. She denies any symptoms of hypertension. 
Plan: 
- Start hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Qday. 
- Instruct patient to monitor her blood pressure at home using a blood pressure cuff and enter the results in Epic MyChart. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up of her blood pressure and chest pain.

CHIEF COMPLAINT
Shortness of breath, fatigue, weight gain, increased urination.

The patient is a 46-year-old female who presents with shortness of breath, fatigue, weight gain, and increased urination. She reports that she has been experiencing shortness of breath for the past two weeks, particularly when lying down. She denies any dyspnea with activity. She also notes that her pulse ox is 92% at home, which is low. The patient states that she is unable to take Lasix due to cost. She also admits that she has not been monitoring her blood sugars. Her last HgbA1C was 7.5%. She has been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, but these symptoms started before her current problems began. She also experiences occasional burning sensations in her feet and hands.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports she has been experiencing shortness of breath for approximately 2 weeks, particularly when lying down. She denies any fevers or chills. She states she has been coughing up mucus once in a while, especially in the morning. She denies any nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. She denies any urinary frequency or dysuria. She denies any weakness or numbness in her legs.

The patient reports she has a history of diabetes and back pain. She states she takes metformin for her diabetes, although she is unsure of the dosage. She reports she has been experiencing back pain for several months, primarily in the lower back. She denies any midline tenderness. She reports she has tried Naprosyn and Flexeril for her back pain without relief.

The patient states she has a history of CHF and COPD. She denies any recent changes in her respiratory status. She reports she has been using Albuterol and Atrovent inhalers for her COPD. She denies any recent changes in her hearing.

The patient reports she has been experiencing weight gain and swelling in her ankles. She denies any calf tenderness or guarding. She denies any bruits or homans sign. She denies any blood clots.

The patient reports she has been experiencing shortness of breath, particularly when lying down. She denies any chest pain or tightness. She denies any palpitations. She denies any dizziness or lightheadedness.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Shortness of breath, back pain, and difficulty sleeping.

The patient is a 46-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for shortness of breath, back pain, and difficulty sleeping. She reports she has been experiencing shortness of breath for the past two weeks, particularly when lying down. She denies any shortness of breath during the day or with exercise. She also reports weight gain and swelling in her legs. She denies any nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. She states she has been taking Lasix and following a diet to prevent salt intake, but admits she has not been taking Lasix regularly. She denies any chest pain or tightness. Her blood sugars have been running a little high, and she has not been checking Accu-Cheks recently. She reports her hemoglobin A1C was 7.5 last time it was checked. She denies any weakness or numbness in her legs.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Shortness of breath due to CHF exacerbation 
Assessment: The patient presents with shortness of breath, increased weight, and edema in her ankles. She denies fever, cough, or sputum production. Her CXR showed no acute cardiopulmonary process. Differential diagnosis includes PNA vs. asthma attack. However, she denied any changes in her respiratory status and her CXR was clear. Therefore, we will focus on treating her CHF exacerbation. 
Plan: 
- Increase Lasix from 20mg to 60mg Qday.

- Recommending icing the knee once an hour for 15 minutes.

She reports a right breast lumpectomy on January 20, 2020, and has been doing regular breast self-exams since then. Her last mammogram was in January 2021 and was normal. The patient denies any recent weight loss or gain, headache, bone pain, urinary symptoms, or blood in the stools. However, she does report back pain, joint pain, and high cholesterol. She takes CoQ10, vitamin D, vitamin C, fish oil, and elderberry fruit for these conditions.

MEDICAL HISTORY
History of stage 0 ER/PR positive invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast (post-lumpectomy with removal of five lymph nodes that were benign). History of radiation therapy but declined endocrine therapy. High cholesterol.

FAMILY HISTORY
No family history of breast cancer. Mother had non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and father had prostate cancer and heart disease.

Social history
Smoked in the past but quit approximately 30 years ago. Drinks socially but never more than that. No illicit drug use.

Allergies
Penicillin allergy.

Her depression is stable, and she continues to take Effexor. She also takes Gabapentin for chronic back pain, which helps control her pain. However, she occasionally experiences severe lower back pain that requires bedrest. She wishes to start practicing yoga again but has not yet made it a habit.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Shortness of breath 
Assessment: Patient presents with shortness of breath, associated with light exercise or ambulation. She also reports increased frequency of episodes. Her pulmonary function tests suggest possible COPD. Physical exam reveals mild wheezes in all lung fields. 
Plan: 
- Diagnose COPD. 
- Start Combivent (2 puffs BID) and Albuterol (2 puffs PRN). 
- Prescribe Prednisone Taper Pack. 
- Continue Effexor XR for depression. 
- Encourage yoga for depression and back pain. 
2. Depression 
Assessment: Patient reports feeling "low" sometimes, although she denies suicidal ideation. She continues to take Effexor XR. 
Plan: 
- Continue Effexor XR. 
3. Chronic Back Pain 
Assessment: Patient reports chronic back pain. She takes Gabapentin Neurontin for pain control. 
Plan: 
- Continue Gabapentin Neurontin. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week to follow up on response to treatment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Shortness of breath 
Assessment: The patient presents with shortness of breath, palpitations, and mild wheezes in all lung fields. She has a history of smoking and depression. Pulmonary function tests suggest asthma or COPD. Chest X-ray shows flattened diaphragm, consistent with COPD. Physical exam reveals mild wheezes in all lung fields. 
Plan:
- Diagnose the patient with COPD.
- Prescribe Combivent (ipratropium bromide) 2 puffs BID.
- Prescribe Albuterol 2 puffs PRN.
- Prescribe Prednisone Taper Pack.
2. Depression
Assessment: The patient reports feeling depressed sometimes. She takes Effexor for her depression.
Plan:
- Continue Effexor.
3. Chronic Back Pain
Assessment: The patient reports chronic back pain. She takes Gabapentin (neurontin) for her back pain.
Plan:
- Continue Gabapentin (neurontin).
- Recommend yoga.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Evaluation of right index finger.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant, cooperative, healthy male who presents to the clinic for evaluation of his right index finger. He reports that he sustained a hyperextension injury of the right index finger during a motor vehicle accident in March of this year. He declined an injection of A1 poly region due to a previous reaction to dexamethasone, which caused him to experience heart racing. The patient underwent MRI of the right index finger on April 24, 2021, which showed a partially torn fds tendon and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the fds and FDP tendons. He has been seen at Point May Orthopedics, where he received X-rays of the right hand today, which revealed no bony abnormalities, joint congruency throughout all lesser digits, no soft tissue shadows of concern, and no arthritis. The patient reported that while he can bend the finger, he cannot make a fist without experiencing significant discomfort. He works as an X-ray technician and suffers from itching with methylprednisolone.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presents to the clinic for a second opinion regarding the right index finger. He sustained a hyperextension injury of the right index finger during a motor vehicle accident in March of this year. The patient declined an injection of A1 polyregion due to a previous reaction to dexamethasone, which causes his heart to race. He underwent an MRI of the right finger on 4/24/2021, which revealed focal soft tissue swelling over the right index MCP joint, partial-thickness tear of the right FDS, and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the FDP and FDS tendons. Radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index MCP joint were intact, as was the MCP joint capsulectomy. Extensor tendons were also deemed intact. An X-ray of the right hand today shows no bony abnormalities, joint congruency throughout all lesser digits on the right hand, no soft tissue shadows of concern, and no arthritis. The patient reports that he is unable to make a fist and experiences pain while performing daily activities such as driving.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Second opinion regarding right index finger injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presents for a second opinion regarding his right index finger injury. He sustained the injury in a motor vehicle accident in March, and he was initially evaluated by Dr. Alice Davis. An MRI of the right index finger was performed due to concern about a capsular strain plus or minus rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendons. The MRI showed focal soft tissue swelling over the right index metacarpophalangeal joint, partial-thickness tear of the FDS tendon, and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the FDP and FDS tendons. Radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index metacarpophalangeal joint were intact, and the joint capsule was intact. Extensor tendons were also deemed intact. The patient reports that he has been seeing an orthopedic surgeon and undergoing physical therapy. However, he is unsatisfied with their treatment and is seeking a second opinion.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis
Assessment: The patient presents with persistent pain and swelling in his right knee, despite prior steroid injection and current treatment with Xeljanz and Celebrex. He also reports worsening swelling in his left leg. Physical exam reveals diminished range of motion in the right knee and pitting edema in both knees and ankles. X-ray of the right knee shows effusion and osteophyte formation.
Plan:
- Will obtain X-ray of the left knee to assess for similar findings.
- Will schedule a physical therapy evaluation to determine if there are any exercises that may help improve mobility and reduce pain.
- Will refer the patient to a surgeon for consideration of surgical intervention if conservative measures fail.
- Will continue Xeljanz 11mg QD and Celebrex 200mg QD.
- Will instruct the patient to elevate his legs whenever possible, wear compression stockings, and limit his dietary sodium.
- Will monitor the patient's blood chemistry panel every 2-3 months to ensure that his liver function tests remain within normal limits.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for repeat assessment of his symptoms and response to treatment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis
Assessment: Patient presents with worsening pain, swelling, and edema in the right knee, consistent with RA flare. He reports decreased effectiveness of Xeljanz and Celebrex. Physical exam reveals reduced ROM, pitting edema, and warmth in the right knee.
Plan:
- Will provide fluid aspiration and steroid injection in the right knee.
- Will order x-ray of the right knee.
- Will refer to physical therapy.
- Will monitor CMP levels every 2 months.
2. Edema in the lower extremities
Assessment: Patient reports new edema in both legs, worse in the right leg. Exam reveals pitting edema and warmth in the right leg.
Plan:
- Will obtain x-ray of the right leg.
- Will discuss lifestyle modifications such as low sodium diet, elevating legs, and using compression stockings.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
Assessment: Patient presents with worsening RA symptoms, including increased pain and swelling in the right knee. He reports that previous steroid injection provided temporary relief, but the pain and swelling have returned. Physical exam reveals decreased range of motion in the right knee and pitting edema in the right knee and ankle. X-ray shows effusion in the right knee.
Plan:
- Will provide steroid injection in the right knee.
- Will order CMP to monitor liver function and electrolytes.
- Will refer to physical therapy.
- Will consider surgery consult if conservative measures fail.
- Encourage patient to reduce sodium intake and elevate legs whenever possible.
2. Edema in the Legs
Assessment: Patient reports bilateral lower extremity edema, likely due to venous insufficiency.
Plan:
- Will obtain X-ray of the left knee to rule out septic joint.
- Will recommend compression stockings and elevating the legs.
- Will encourage patient to reduce sodium intake.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Acne rosacea
Assessment: The patient has acne rosacea, which has improved with doxycycline monotherapy. However, she reports increased dryness with twice-daily application of the sulfacetamide wash, and therefore plans to switch to once-daily application. She continues to use the metrocream and elidel creams.
Plan:
- Continue doxycycline monotherapy, twice daily
- Continue washing her face with sulfacetamide wash once daily.
- Start elidel cream, discussed about goodRx coupon. If not covered, she can consider using Eucrisa instead.
- Hold off on using any other products (e.g., cetaphil cleanser, Neutrogena wipes) until seen again in follow-up.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 month for assessment of response to treatment and further management.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Acne rosacea 
Assessment: The patient has acne rosacea, which is improving with treatment. However, she has developed a new rash on her face, likely due to the doxycycline. She is currently using sulfacetamide wash, metrocream, and elidel. 
Plan: 
- Continue sulfacetamide wash and metrocream. 
- Add elidel to the regimen. 
- Increase doxycycline to twice a day. 
- Instruct the patient to continue using the same face wash and metro cream, and increase the use of doxycycline to twice a day. 
- If the rash starts to flair again, instruct the patient to hold off until seen again by the doctor before restarting any of her old products.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Rosacea
Assessment: The patient has rosacea, which is improving with treatment. However, she reports that her symptoms have plateaued recently. She is currently using doxycycline 100mg Qday, which she believes is contributing to her dry skin. She denies any history of heart transplant, kidney transplant, or cancer.
Plan:
- Continue doxycycline 100mg Qday.
- Add elidel cream 0.1% 1 applicator Qday.
- Instruct the patient to avoid using cetaphil cleanser, Neutrogena wipes, and lotions.
- Instruct the patient to use a goodrx coupon for elidel cream.
- If the patient experiences any side effects from doxycycline, instruct her to discontinue its use and contact the office.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular Age-related Macular Degeneration (wet AMD) 
Assessment: Patient presented with sudden visual distortions, blurring of vision, and difficulty adjusting to dim lighting. Exam revealed posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, drusen deposits, retinal pigment epithelium subretinal fluid accumulation, choroidal neovascular membrane, and focal areas of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular age-related macular degeneration. Fluorescein angiography revealed focal areas of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular age-related macular degeneration. Diagnosis: Neovascular Age-related Macular Degeneration (wet AMD). 
Plan: 
- Will initiate treatment with Lucentes once a month, injected into the vitreous portion of the eye after it's been numbed. Injections are given regularly over a period of time to slow the rate of vision decline or stop further vision loss. However, the disease and loss may also progress despite treatment. 
2. Smoking: Assessment: Patient reports continued smoking a pack of cigarettes daily despite attempts to quit. 
Plan: 
- Continue counseling on smoking cessation. 
3. Hypertension: Assessment: Patient reports taking blood pressure medication occasionally. Blood pressure check during visit showed elevated blood pressure. 
Plan: 
- Recommend regular monitoring of blood pressure at home and frequent checks by healthcare provider. 
4. Hyperlipidemia: Assessment: Patient does not report current treatment for hyperlipidemia. 
Plan: 
- Consider starting statin therapy if lipid panel indicates high risk for cardiovascular disease. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 6 weeks for repeat evaluation of response to treatment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD) 
Assessment: The patient presented with sudden visual distortions, blurred vision, and difficulty adjusting to dim lighting. The diagnosis of neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD) was confirmed by ocular coherence tomography (OCT), fluorescein angiography, and fundoscopy. 
Plan: 
- Will initiate treatment with Lucentis (ranibizumab) injections once a month. 
- Patient will need regular monitoring of blood pressure and blood sugar control. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient reported taking her blood pressure only occasionally. She was advised to monitor her blood pressure regularly and keep a log. 
Plan: 
- Continue education on importance of blood pressure management. 
3. Smoking cessation 
Assessment: The patient reports difficulty quitting smoking. 
Plan: 
- Provide counseling on smoking cessation. 
4. Diabetes 
Assessment: The patient reports taking her blood sugar medicine only sometimes. 
Plan: 
- Encourage compliance with diabetes medications. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for repeat evaluation and injection.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration (wet AMD) 
Assessment: The patient presents with sudden visual distortions, blurring of vision, decreased vision when reading and straight lines, and difficulty adjusting to dim lighting. These symptoms are consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD). The patient's anterior segment examination revealed posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, clear corneas, and no mvi, pciol, cup to disc ratio of .2 in the right eye. Fundus examination showed the retina to be attached three hundred and sixty degrees without any tears or holes or pe changes in the fovea. Posterior segment exam showed drusen in the macula, thickening of the retina, presence of subretinal fluid and exudates accumulation, and positive for hemorrhage in the left eye. Fluorescein angiography revealed focal areas of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular age-related macular degeneration. Diagnosis: Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration (wet AMD). 
Plan: 
- Will administer Lucentis once a month via injection into the vitreous portion of the eye after it's been numbed. Injections are given regularly over a period of time it may slow the rate of vision decline or stop further vision loss. However, the disease and loss it may also progress despite treatment. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks for reassessment.
2. Smoking
Assessment: The patient continues to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day despite efforts to quit.
Plan:
- Encourage the patient to continue trying to quit smoking.
3. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient takes blood pressure medication occasionally.
Plan:
- Recommend regular blood pressure checks at home.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbation due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension. 
Assessment: Patient has history of CHF, EF 55%, moderate MR, and mild AR. She presented with increased SOB, orthopnea, and PND. Her BP was elevated to 200/90. Physical exam showed JVD, crackles on lung exam, and trace pedal edema. Echo shows preserved EF, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate MR. 
Plan: 
- Continue bumex 2mg Qd. 
- Dietary counseling and education. Avoid salty foods. 
- Weigh herself daily and call doctor if gains 3lbs in 2days. 
- Nutritionist consult. 
2. Hypertension
Assessment: Patient has history of HTN. Blood pressure was elevated to 200/90. 
Plan: 
- Continue Cozaar 100mg Qd. 
- Add Norvasc 5mg Qd. 
- Renal artery ultrasound. 
3. Kidney disease
Assessment: Patient has a history of CKD. Lab values showed Cr 1.7. 
Plan: 
- Obtain labs to monitor response to new meds. 
4. Shortness of breath
Assessment: Patient denied shortness of breath since being discharged from the hospital. 
Plan: 
- Monitor closely. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 3months or sooner if symptoms return.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Abdominal Pain due to Gastritis
Assessment: Patient presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which worsened over time. She has a history of diabetes and alcohol use. Exam revealed mild tenderness in the epigastrium of her abdomen without signs of obstruction. Differential diagnosis includes gastritis vs. pancreatitis.
Plan:
- Will start Zantac 2x/day for 4 weeks.
- Recommend cutting back on caffeine and alcohol consumption.
- Ordered CBC, comprehensive metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine pregnancy test.

2. Diabetes Type 2
Assessment: Patient has a history of poorly controlled diabetes. She is currently taking Metformin 500mg BID.
Plan:
- Increase Metformin to 1000mg QAM and 500mg QPM.
- Continue monitoring blood sugar levels.

3. Asthma
Assessment: Patient has a history of asthma and reports occasional wheezing. She currently takes Flovent twice a day and Albuterol PRN.
Plan:
- Continue Flovent 2 puffs twice a day.
- Continue Albuterol PRN for wheezing.
- Encourage smoking cessation.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Abdominal pain 
Assessment: Acute gastritis likely due to excessive caffeine and alcohol consumption. No fever, no leukocytosis, no anemia. 
Plan: 
- Cut back on caffeine and alcohol intake. 
- Zantac 2x/day for 4 weeks. 
- Urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, CBC, Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP) ordered. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise. 
2. Diabetes Type II 
Assessment: Under good control. HbA1c 8%. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg QAM and 1000mg QPM. 
- Monitor blood sugar levels regularly. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise. 
3. Asthma 
Assessment: No current exacerbation. 
Plan: 
- Continue Flovent 220mcg BID and Albuterol PRN. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Abdominal pain due to gastritis
Assessment: The patient has a history of diabetes, asthma, and heavy caffeine and alcohol use. She has been experiencing gradual increase in abdominal pain over the past week, associated with nausea and vomiting. Physical exam reveals mild tenderness in the epigastrium. Differential diagnosis includes gastroenteritis, peptic ulcer disease, and irritable bowel syndrome.
Plan:
- Will obtain urinalysis, urine pregnancy test, CBC, and comprehensive metabolic panel.
- Will start Zantac 2x/day.
- Recommend cutting back on caffeine and alcohol consumption.
- Recommend avoiding spicy food.
2. Diabetes Type II
Assessment: The patient has a history of diabetes and is currently controlled on metformin 500mg QHS. 
Plan:
- Increase morning metformin to 1000mg.
- Continue current dosage of metformin 500mg QHS.
- Monitor blood sugar levels.
3. Asthma
Assessment: The patient has a history of asthma and is currently controlled on Flovent 2 puff BID and Albuterol PRN.
Plan:
- Continue Flovent 2 puff BID.
- Use Albuterol PRN.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks.

Recurrent lower respiratory infections.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of recurrent lower respiratory infections. The patient reports that he has been experiencing recurrent lower respiratory infections for approximately 6 months, occurring every month or every other month. He notes that his symptoms typically begin shortly after unloading hay. His symptoms include coughing, increased mucous production, shortness of breath, and low-grade fevers. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Recurrent lung infections (Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis)
Assessment: Patient presents with recurrent lung infections, coughing, mucus production, and shortness of breath. Chest X-ray shows round glass opacities. Exam reveals fine rales on lung exam but no wheezes. Differential diagnosis includes Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis vs. Farmer's Lung. 
Plan: 
- Will start oral prednisone 40mg Qday for 2 weeks. 
- Order CT scan of the lungs and Pulmonary Function Test. 
- Recommend avoiding exposure to hay or wear a respirator when moving hay. 
- Follow-up in 2 weeks.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Hallux rigidus 
Assessment: The patient presents with a history of left great toe pain, swelling, and erythema for 2 weeks. He reports increased pain last week while attending a trade show convention. Examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the first metatarsophalangeal joint, limited dorsiflexion, and plantarflexion of the great toe, and crepitus. X-ray shows loss of articular cartilage, enlargement of the proximal phalanx, and degenerative changes suggestive of hallux rigidus. 
Plan: 
- Will prescribe orthotics and meloxicam 7.5mg daily. 
- Instruct patient to return in 2 weeks for follow-up. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- If symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, consider changing medication or referring to podiatry. 
- Avoid heavy lifting and twisting motions to minimize strain on the great toe joint.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Hallux rigidus 
Assessment: The patient presents with left big toe pain, swelling, and limited mobility. X-ray shows loss of cartilage, spur formation, and arthritis. 
Plan: 
- Will prescribe orthotics and meloxicam 7.5 mg Qday. 
- Instruct the patient to avoid excessive activity and use ice packs as needed. 
- If symptoms persist or worsen, will consider alternative treatments such as corticosteroid injection or surgery. 
2. Possible gastrointestinal irritation from NSAIDs 
Assessment: The patient reports history of GI upset with NSAIDs. 
Plan: 
- Will monitor the patient closely for signs of gastrointestinal irritation while on meloxicam. 
- If symptoms occur, will discontinue meloxicam and recommend alternative treatments.

- Will follow up in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment. If symptoms persist, will consider surgical intervention.
